StudentProfile.TeaserText: Post 9/11 GI Bill® and Vocational Rehab have tremendously helped me to be able to attend Oregon Tech
StudentProfile.Biography:
Where are you from?

Originally, I am from Russia. However, I have lived in Oregon since 2001. I lived in Virginia for six of those years because the Navy stationed me there.

Veteran status/branch of military and rank upon leaving: Damage Controlman/ E3/Navy

Awards/Accomplishments while at Oregon Tech: ASOIT representative for the Dental Hygiene Program

Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech because the Dental Hygiene program comes highly recommended. I wanted to get a Bachelor’s degree and I will be able to do that at this school. After coming back from Virginia, I wanted to stay in Oregon and go to school here because I love this magical state. I was ecstatic to get accepted into the Oregon Tech Dental Hygiene Program.

Did the Post 9/11 GI Bill® option at Oregon Tech influence your decision to come here?

Yes, absolutely. Post 9/11 GI Bill® and Vocational Rehab have tremendously helped me to be able to attend Oregon Tech. I would not be at this school if I did not have that financial backing. I would attempt to get into cheaper community colleges that offer associates degrees in my field of interest. I am beyond blessed and thankful to have VA in my corner. I hope that one day I can repay back all the goodness that they have done for me and help treat my fellow veterans through dental work.

What do you like most about your program?

I love that I am constantly learning something new. I like the challenge and I like that my program has caring instructors that will help me be successful in this field. I know that I am getting the best education I could possibly get. In addition to that, my program has a lot of community health outreach in which I am looking forward to getting to do.

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

In a perfect world, I would want everyone to be able to get dental care regardless of their financial situation. I grew up in poverty and dental care as a child for me was nonexistent in our country. I hope that one day everyone in the world can have the right to dental care.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

Community Dental Health because I will get to be involved in the community through dental treatment, oral health education and more.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

Yes, I would like everyone to know that we are offering very low cost cleanings, x-rays, sealants, oral cancer screenings, fluoride treatments and much more at our dental hygiene clinic. We are located in Semon Hall 218.

Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation?

I plan on working in public health or in a private dental office. I will definitely stay in Oregon however, not sure what my exact location will be.

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

I find Klamath Falls campus to be a peaceful place. I was caught off guard how much it snows here and I was having a hard time getting to school in my Toyota Camry. So to the future students from out of the area be prepared to come to school and make sure your vehicle is up to par for the snow conditions.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Choose a major that sparks your curiosity, and even if you have to take one or two “bad” classes, it will be easier to get through them because you will be excited for the rest of the classes
StudentProfile.Biography:
Awards/Accomplishments while at Oregon Tech:
  • President’s list for two terms
  • Awarded the Coleman Family Scholarship and Presidential Scholarship
  • TOP Honors Student

    • Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

    I chose Oregon Tech because I wanted a technical approach to my education. As a math major, I wanted to learn the uses of my favorite subject in classes with a direct application to my future career as an analyst. As opposed to other universities, Oregon Tech promised this type of education centered on Applied Math. So far, Oregon Tech has kept this promise and I’ve enjoyed learning the skills I will need in the future.

    What do you like most about your program?

    Many people don’t like math because it doesn’t seem applicable. But, since Oregon Tech offers the Applied Math program, students can learn how math is applied everywhere. The math professors center their lessons on applications and are happy to entertain ideas of where and how math can be applied. The biggest complaint you hear about math is “When are we even going to use this?” But in my program, that question is answered daily, and that is my favorite aspect of the program.

    What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

    Math has such a bad connotation among people. While it can definitely be frustrating at times, it also answers the world’s most asked questions. If I could change anything in the math field, it would be how people view math. I hope to show others that math can be an eloquent solution, rather than a last resort, to everyday questions, as well as questions that have yet to be answered.

    What would be your dream job?

    My dream job would be to help my employer with their math- related questions. Whether that is by calculating the efficiencies of products, analyzing data to answer research questions, or numerous other questions that the world needs answers for. I want to use the skills that I’m learning now to help others (e.g. employers, peers, or students) understand how math is used to answer their questions.

    What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

    So far, my favorite classes have been the Calculus series and some geomatics courses, particularly Computations and Platting. These have been my favorite courses because of how applicable math is in them. The reasoning behind the Calculus series is obvious, but I’ve really enjoyed how math is applied in land surveying. Surveyors use geometry, algebra, and calculus to do their jobs. I enjoy the practical use of these math courses that tend to be overlooked or hated because they seem “pointless.”

    Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

    Everyone should know about how many resources are offered at Oregon Tech to help students succeed. For example, there’s the Tutoring center, Career Services, and the Tech Opportunities Program (TOP) for first-generation and/or low-income students. There are also many resources in the library, such as laptops available for checkout, research services, whiteboard tables, etc. Coming to Oregon Tech, I was surprised how many resources were available, but am grateful for them, as these resources have helped me with quite a few classes.

    Are you involved on campus?

    Yes, I’m currently a Peer Consultant in the Tutoring Center. My job is to help students with their understanding of their coursework. Students can make appointments or walk-in for help on homework and studying for their classes. The Tutoring Center has helped me with difficult classes, and in return, I enjoy helping others in the same situation.  

    Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation?

    At this point, my plan after graduation is to find employment as a Research Analyst. This career only requires a bachelor’s degree, but I may decide to attend graduate school, for more knowledge and experience in a specified field. I hope to remain on the West Coast, but am open to many career options as an analyst.

    Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

    For future students, who are undecided of their major: Look through the required classes for the majors that sound the most interesting. I was able to find a major that was best for me by looking at the courses offered in the majors I was interested in and narrow down my choice by seeing the number of classes I would enjoy for each major. If you’re looking through the required classes of a major and a majority of classes sound boring and/or dreadful, that may not be the best major for you. Choose a major that sparks your curiosity, and even if you have to take one or two “bad” classes, it will be easier to get through them because you will be excited for the rest of the classes. College is a chance for you to expand your knowledge in a topic that inspires you. Don’t waste the experience torturing yourself with uninteresting classes. Also, if you enjoy learning the skills needed for a career, isn’t it reasonable to assume you’ll enjoy that career? If you hate the classes that give you the skills for a career, why would you like that career?

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I chose Oregon Tech because it is an inclusive university that beds creativity, multiculturism and innovation with one of the top 4 best Renewable Energy programs in the United States
StudentProfile.Biography:
1. Why did you choose Oregon Tech? Each person in this world is born with specific characteristics, strengths and unique qualities that define them. I’m a person that is eager to understand teamwork structures and Oregon Tech has given me the scenarios to excel and improve as a person and engineer. I chose Oregon Tech because it is an inclusive university that beds creativity, multiculturism and innovation with one of the top 4 best Renewable Energy programs in the United States
  2. What do you like most about your program? As a graduate student, I found fascinating the opportunity to discuss with high skill experts in the field, the professors are the ones that make this program attractive, their expertise and their willingness to share, discuss, create projects along with students is what I like the most about the program. This is a university that is always inviting you to think outside the box, to go against the current and propose alternative solutions to existing issues.
  3. What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why? Renewable Energy engineers are characterized by having a holistic view of the energy field. Even though this program focuses on the renewable energy technologies, it also teaches thoroughly how to integrate current energy practices with alternative energy processes; exposing us in a field that is seeking for changes that require the capacity to understand and incorporate both traditional and renewable energy practices to achieve sustainability. As for me I’m passionate about improving energy planning strategies, understanding teamwork structures and innovating energy strategies to fulfill my passion for effectively leading energy projects where both fields must work together.
  4. What would be your dream job? Being an Energy Analyst – where the holistic view will allow me and my team to integrate knowledge from different areas of expertise proposing practical solutions to future energy requirements.
  5. What have been some of your favorite classes and why? I honestly have enjoyed all of them. Each class has given me a very particular knowledge of the field that I didn’t have before.  However, If I must pick I will go with Electricity Markets, Solar PV and research and innovation. These classes have built me as a professional integrating renewable energy knowledge with research and innovation strategies while understanding the Business/Market -Economic-Technical aspect of the field.
  6. Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about? Yes, this has become my second home. As an international, immersion into a new culture can take time, this university has very caring faculty and staff that is ready to push you, motivate you and guide you to achieve your professional and personal goals.
  7. Are you involved on campus? Yes, I am.I work for the EERE department as a graduate assistant and research assistant.
  8. Have you participated in any internships or externships during your time at Oregon Tech? When I was part of the International Department, I had the chance to work for Klamath Falls campus for the summer. During those 3 months, we were able to create the “ISS Communication plan” strategy for the institution that is aimed to systematize communication procedures for the international community.
  9. Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about the campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else? Yes, I invite incoming students to reach out to their future professors, to use the platforms such as student services, and to contact our student ambassadors. This is key at the time of making the right decision for which program to study.

Awards/Accomplishments while at Oregon Tech

Graduate Assistant EERE Department

  • Developing a “matching degree course tool” that sorts the engineering courses based on course description. The mission was to reduce duplicate courses that can be merged helping Oregon Tech to standardize engineering principles.
  • Developed a user-friendly advising tool across multiple engineering majors that helps advisors to address degree planning in a time efficient manner. Used Excel to build dynamic curriculum map for all the engineering programs at Oregon Tech Portland-Metro & Klamath Falls campus.

     

    International Assistant Portland Metro Campus

  • Formulated and supported the “ISS 2019 Communication plan strategy” of Oregon Tech that systemize International processes and communication procedures to improve interaction with the International community.

Oregon Renewable Energy Center (OREC) | Transnational Applied Research

Conducting transnational research to develop a model of unit price demand elasticity of the renewable energy attributes of Colombia. (MASTER THESIS)

  • Pursuing to formulate the best methodology / prospective method for the analysis and quantification of the residential energy demand and consumer preference of Colombia. The result of this research will be a high applicable methodology that decision-makers can use to maximize renewable energy penetration while understanding the cost and risk involved. Also, this model will allow developing countries to improve energy planning procedures.
  • Developing the modeling procedures that incorporate behavioral economics into loads forecasting and resource planning modeling.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: At only 20 years old, Olga graduated with highest honors from Oregon Tech’s MLS program in December 2018, the youngest in her class.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Volha “Olga” Uhlianitsa was introduced to Oregon Tech through her high school guidance counselor who was familiar with the university’s Portland-Metro High School Transition (HST) Program. The HST allows high school students to access Oregon Tech coursework for only $25 per credit hour, encouraging college and career exploration while lowering costs for families.

Olga was an extremely motivated, high achieving student who attended Clackamas Web Academy, accessing accelerated coursework through Clackamas Community College (CCC). She had a passion for STEM and learned about Oregon Tech’s Medical Laboratory Science program through her sister. Working closely with Oregon Tech’s HST Program and CCC, Olga was able to complete all of the prerequisite coursework needed to apply to the MLS program. Some of these courses included 300/400 level Biology courses such as Immunology and Medical Microbiology, but that level of difficulty didn’t stop Olga from working towards her career goal.

Through a competitive application process, Olga was admitted to Oregon Tech’s MLS program while she was also receiving her high school diploma. Two years later, at only 20 years old, Olga graduated with highest honors from Oregon Tech’s MLS program in December 2018, the youngest in her class. Also impressive was Olga being chosen by her classmates and faculty as the Outstanding Medical Laboratory Science Student in their graduating class; awarded to students who are professional, respected by peers, dedicated to helping others, and have technical ability, initiative, integrity, and communication skills. Olga has already received at least one job offer in Oregon, a field in which Oregon Tech graduates are earning average starting salaries of about $56,000 a year.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: If it wasn’t for the professors, this program would not be among the best in the nation, they are the unsung heroes of Oregon Tech.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Awards/Accomplishments while at Oregon Tech: 4 Year Oregon Tech Baseball player, multiple Dean and President’s List appearances,

  1. Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

    Originally, I chose Oregon Tech because I was drawn to the medical imaging modalities and I could play baseball at the collegiate level. Upon arrival, I realized that the imaging modalities were definitely not what I wanted to do. I stumbled upon the Respiratory Therapy program and the rest was history. That choice turned out to be the best decision to date.

  2. What do you like most about your program?

    The thing I enjoy most about my program is the personal relationships built with the professors. I don’t think of them as traditional educators, but more as mentors. They go above and beyond what the curriculum requires, and they provide sound advice about life and personal decisions. If it wasn’t for them, this program would not be among the best in the nation, they are the unsung heroes of Oregon Tech.

  3. What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

    I am passionate about cultivating a new culture in respiratory therapy with my cohort. Traditionally, RTs were looked down upon and did not have many responsibilities. I feel that our class is much more capable and is going to pave the way for more autonomy and responsibility in the medical workforce.

  4. What would be your dream job?

    My dream job would be performing helicopter transport with my degree. I want to be there for a patient’s worst day and use my education and clinical skills to give them the best possible chance to see another day.

  5. What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

    My favorite class has been CHE 360 (Pharmacology) because it was by far the most challenging class I’ve ever taken at Oregon Tech. That class pushed me to my limits and gave me perspective on how hard my classes really are. It was the most gratifying because I ended up pulling an “A” out and showed me that I’m capable of much more than I ever thought I could be.

  6. Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

    The respiratory therapy program, Oregon Tech’s best kept secret. Oregon Tech is known for the engineering and imaging degrees, but in my opinion, the respiratory therapy program is the least talked about and most rewarding program here.

  7. Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation?

The best thing about the respiratory therapy program is the high job placement rate. There is a high demand for RTs so I don’t have to get sucked into a hospital I don’t want to be at. Right now the focus is to graduate, then I’ll see where the wind takes me.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Oregon Tech is so unique that by the time we are ready to graduate we are “job ready” and that gives us an advantage...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Major: Manufacturing & Mechanical Engineering (Undergraduate) and Manufacturing Engineering (Graduate Degree)
Hometown: Eugene, OR

Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech because of the hands-on experience with the engineering programs and the high employment rates after graduation.

What do you like best about your major?

The best thing about the engineering programs is that we can take the theoretical knowledge and apply it to practical situations. Oregon Tech is so unique that by the time we are ready to graduate we are “job ready” and that gives us an advantage when applying for jobs.

What would be your dream job in your major?

My dream job would be to start my own company in the manufacturing industry. There is no greater feeling than to take a raw material and turning it into a finished good.

What’s your favorite thing to do off campus?

My favorite things I have found to do off campus is to check out Mt. Shasta to go snowboarding, or go to the Klamath or Williamson river to go fishing.

What’s your most memorable moment on campus?

My most memorable moment on campus is creating and finishing the first Oregon Tech Composite Drift boat and floating it in the fountain.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I enjoy being involved with the on campus Radiologic Science Club...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech because I wanted to boost my knowledge in a hands-on learning environment and secure a stable career. Oregon Tech offers a Bachelor’s Degree in Radiologic Science, one of the only schools to reputably do so on the West Coast. With its partnership with Sky Lakes Hospital, Oregon Tech allows its medical students to perform observations in our fields of study. Also, Oregon Tech is a campus that is open to growth; it evolves with the time and the needs of a student entering a technologically-dependent society.

What do you like best about your major?

As a sophomore in the Radiologic Science Program, I enjoy being involved with the on campus Radiologic Science Club and spending time in the state-of-the-art laboratory suites. The faculty is supportive with both academic and non-academic goals; doing their best to help students exceed their potential. And, the best part is, all of this is done with like-minded and dedicated students.

What would be your dream job in your major?

Throughout my life, I have sustained four concussions and all of them played a part in finding my passion and career: healthcare. My dream job would be to become a Magnetic Resonance Imaging Tech that is specialized in imaging Brain Trauma. With this, I could bridge my volunteer service of Athletic Concussion Awareness and education with my career.

What’s your favorite thing to do off campus?

I love to spend time outdoors! Klamath is wonderful for bird watching, hiking, camping, boating, bonfires, snowy activities, and so much more. Crater Lake National Park is less than two hours away…and also, just over the hill there is enough tax-free shopping to satisfy anything that the heart desires.

What’s your most memorable moment on campus?

This year, fellow medical student Megan Cook and I hosted Oregon Tech’s First Annual Mr. OIT Pageant benefiting the Children’s Miracle Network Hospitals. We raised over $650 for this phenomenal organization in addition to a $500 scholarship for our winner. This was a great event and definitely one of my favorite moments on campus thus far.

Miss Oregon 2013 - Allison Cook (Southern Gem)

"To be representing a state such as Oregon is such an honor and I cannot wait to begin my year of service with Children's Miracle Network, the Red Cross and promoting concussion awareness."

Read more: Oregon Tech Student Wins Miss Oregon 2013

Read more about Oregon Tech’s accolades and university achievements at www.oit.edu/kudos

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I was drawn to the fact that the MSREE program is the first of its kind in the United States...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I was drawn to the fact that the MSREE program is the first of its kind in the United States. The curriculum offered at Oregon Tech really matched my career goals, so there was no doubt in my mind that Oregon Tech was the right choice for me. Additionally, I noticed that the faculty at Oregon Tech has a wide range of experience in the professional world, and that is appealing to me.

What do you like best about your major?

The broadness and versatility of classes offered within the program. Because I have a Bachelor’s Degree in Mechanical Engineering, this program is the perfect fit for me, since I am finally applying the theories that I studied during my undergrad in the useful projects that I am currently involved in.

What would be your dream job in your major?

Working as a consultant has always been my dream job. I would love the flexibility of reporting to myself and holding myself accountable for my work as a consultant.

What’s your favorite thing to do off campus?

I’m always exploring and enjoying one of the many activities that the Great Outdoors of the Northwest has to offer. Also, the campus in Wilsonville is convenient for enjoying the spirit of Portland - farmer’s markets, micro-breweries and food carts.

What’s your most memorable moment on campus?

When some fellow students and I were able to charge a cell phone from a solar panel using a simple circuit that we designed.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I chose Oregon Tech because of the small class sizes and student to teacher ratio...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech because of the small class sizes and student to teacher ratio; the teachers also care about the students. It seemed perfect for me because Oregon Tech has the small school feel like a private school, but the tuition and benefits of being a public university. Oregon Tech seemed to have the best program to prepare me for medical school. Lastly, when I visited I felt like I belonged at Oregon Tech because of the great community.

What do you like best about your major?

I like my major because of the variety of classes in the Health Science major. It challenges me and gives me an edge over students from other schools applying to medical school. I love learning about the human body and the teachers are very passionate about the subjects and care about their students.

What would be your dream job in your major?

My dream job is as a surgeon working in a rural hospital. I also would love to volunteer with Medical Teams International or Doctors Without Borders. I just want to help people anyway I can.

What’s your favorite thing to do off campus?

I live on campus so there aren't a lot of things I do off campus, but I enjoy going to the movies with friends. I also love walking downtown to the shops and eating at so many different restaurants.

What’s your most memorable moment on campus?

My most memorable moment was last year, after I had only been in Klamath Falls for a few weeks. My boyfriend and I had just came back to the Res Hall after our first date and we hiked up to the O. We laid in the middle of the O, staring up at the stars. I saw the lights of the city and campus and felt at peace that I had made the right choice to come to Oregon Tech.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I was drawn in by the rich curriculum of the Geomatics Department...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

First of all, I was drawn in by the rich curriculum of the Geomatics Department. From outside, it was well rounded and I believed the school was going to pass through me rather than me through it. I am here now, and my expectations have been more than met. Oregon Tech is just amazing. I’m glad I came.

What do you like best about your major?

The lab time. There’s hands on experience through the lab sessions. This, you can’t find easily. There are simulations of real-world problems we learn to solve. I am inadvertently going to hit the ground running when I graduate. There’s one-on-one interaction between me and the professors on both academic and personal issues. This adds that human element, given the pressures of academic life.

What clubs or activities are you involved with?

I’m a member of the Geomatics and International Students club. I also have the best job on campus as an IT Helpdesk Technician. I fix computers all over campus and help students who call the Helpdesk for help with IT issues. I love it. I get to interact with everyone.

What career do you hope to have after you graduate from Oregon Tech?

I am gunning for a career as a GIS Systems Administrator who understands land surveying techniques. I want to be the link between the land Surveyor and the data that goes online. Someone has to manage and put that data online. I will be that guy.

Do you have any advice for incoming students?

You won’t regret coming to Oregon Tech. The atmosphere is very conducive for learning and make sure you get the best out of the professor. They have so much to offer. Don’t forget to have fun. There are loads of activities on campus that will make for an all-round college experience.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I chose Oregon Tech because it has a strong Geomatics department and supports participation in the MECOP/CECOP internship program...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Accomplishments while at Oregon Tech: Only student to ever receive NAIA recognition 6 times, Team captain for Cross Country, PLSO Scholarships
Current city: Woodburn, OR
Current job title & place of employment (or continuing education school): ODOT in Salem, OR


Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech because it has a strong Geomatics department and supports participation in the MECOP/CECOP internship program. Also, the small class sizes make classes a lot more enjoyable.

What do you like best about your major?

I love the combination of outdoor fieldwork and computer mapping. Being outside along with performing calculations is the perfect balance.

What do you like most about your profession?

I enjoy being outdoors and the math and problem solving that is involved on a daily basis. It never gets old!

How long after graduation did it take you to find a job?

After I graduated I was encouraged by one of my professors, Jack Walker, to attend Purdue University’s grad program in Remote Sensing. It is a 2-year program but I finished in one year while also being a TA in the surveying classes. I got my job at ODOT three months later.

Did you participate in any externships during your time at Oregon Tech?

I spent a summer working at Hawaiian Electric Company in Honolulu, HI.

How do you feel your time at Oregon Tech prepared you for your current job/continuing studies?

All of the hands-on classes at Oregon Tech really prepared me well for my job. At other schools students learn the theory but at Oregon Tech we were actually working with the instruments starting our first year. The CAD classes were also very important for the work I do and if I had not had those courses, I wouldn’t know what to do. Employers don’t have time to train employees so my coding classes at Oregon Tech were really important.

Is there anything you wish you would have done during your time at Oregon Tech that you didn’t?

I wish I would have taken advantage of the Outdoor Program more. I was busy year-round with track and cross country.

Do you maintain professional relationships with any of your professors?

I stay in touch with professors Mason Marker and Jeff Walker. I was also the only woman in my class of 12 students that graduated together and we all keep in touch and still get together.

What advice would you give to a current student at Oregon Tech?

My advice is to spend as much time with your professors outside of class, during their office hours. The professors have industry experience and you can learn so much from them, even outside the classroom.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I believe Oregon Tech’s Health Science faculty is what really makes this program unique and stand out from the rest...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Post-graduate program: School of Medicine at the Oregon Health and Science University

M.D. graduation year: 2020

What are you doing now, career-wise (or what do you plan to do after graduating)?

I am a medical student at the Oregon Health and Science University in Portland, Oregon. As of March 2017, I will be entering a yearlong Pathology Student Fellowship in addition to my medical undergraduate training. After graduating I am hoping to enter a general surgery residency, which is currently on the top of my desired specialty list. Ultimately, I plan to practice as a rural general surgeon on the Oregon Coast.

What is one thing that you really appreciated about our program at Oregon Tech?

Something that really attracted me to Oregon Tech was the anatomy program. The unique opportunity to work with human cadavers is really a great experience. This in addition to the great faculty and courses within the program that helped shape my interest in medicine into an obtainable reality.

The program will push you to develop the study skills and foundation to succeed in graduate programs. I am forever appreciative of the mentors and friends I found within the faculty. I believe Oregon Tech’s Health Science faculty is what really makes this program unique and stand out from the rest.

What advice would you give to a student in our program today?

Enjoy each step of the process of your education. Don’t wait until admission to your desired graduate program to be happy. The road to becoming a medical professional is long and arduous, as many of you know, so it’s important to be in it for the right reasons. Never underestimate the importance of good mental health. Make time for your loved ones and the activities that keep you sane. As my other colleagues have stated, it gets harder to make that time as you progress through your training, so start those good habits now.

Profile updated Mar 2017

StudentProfile.TeaserText: The level of interaction between the students and the faculty is what I like most about my major...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

Originally, as a renewable engineering major, I chose Oregon Tech because of the intensity of the program. I like how Oregon Tech requires classes that strengthen students in ways other institutions don’t. After I changed majors my first year, I found that I appreciated Oregon Tech even more. But one thing remains constant; I always see how programs at Oregon Tech are structured to give students the best possible education in four years. This is very different than a lot of universities that I previewed.

What do you like best about your major?

The level of interaction between the students and the faculty is what I like most about my major. As a student within Health Sciences I know there will always be someone willing to help with class, personal, or academic situations. Due to the willingness of the faculty, as a student I feel that each instructor takes pride in their students and are rooting for them to succeed, not making it impossible to do so.

What would be your dream job in your major?

My dream job would be to work with the WHO (World Health Organization) or CDC as these careers would tie my four major interests with one another; the ability to help people, the aspect of medicine/health, medical sociology and travel. With the new Oregon Tech sociology program under development, I am surrounded within many new opportunities to expand this dream and a great avenue in which to pursue my dream. Many professors within my department and the social sciences department are always there to help work my interests with one another.

What’s your favorite thing to do off campus?

Off campus, one of my favorite things to do is to go dollar bowling on Tuesday and Thursday nights. I also really enjoy volunteering around the community. My favorite volunteering organization would be HEART, a therapeutic riding center located in Klamath Falls. I also enjoy shadowing different health professionals in Klamath Falls and Oregon Tech makes the opportunity to shadow much more prominent due to the presence of the campus so near the major medical facilities of Klamath Falls.

What’s your most memorable moment on campus?

My most memorable moment on campus so far has been my interactions with professors. I approached a professor about an upcoming major/program and I was met with so much enthusiasm I knew I had made the right choice in both attending Oregon Tech and wanting to be part of this new program. The level of excitement the professor felt towards my interest just reinforced my own interest and excitement. It made me see how much the faculty really does care about the education of their students.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I really want to help bridge the communication gap between IT and health professionals...
StudentProfile.Biography:
What do you like best about your major?

I can't wait to get out there and start applying my knowledge in the health world. I really want to help bridge the communication gap between IT and health professionals to facilitate the move to an electronic medical industry.

What would be your dream job in your major?

I also have a passion in graphical user interfacing - so often I hear complaints like "it doesn't let me do what I need it to" or "it works but its clumsy and hard to work with." What do you like best about your major?

I like the daily challenges I am faced with in my major. We are the general ultrasound program so we have to stay on our toes 24/7 with knowing different scanning techniques, pathology, etc. I always have something to do, something new to learn every day and I love it.

What clubs or activities are you involved with?

I am part of the DMS Club on campus and I work Front Desk for the Housing and Residence Life. With my job, I stay involved with different programs and activities on campus.

What career do you hope to have after you graduate from OIT?

After I graduate from OIT, I would love to work at a large hospital somewhere on the west coast. I want to experience the fast paced work lifestyle a large hospital will offer. Down the road, when my life starts to settle down, I picture myself working in a smaller clinic, something not as fast paced.

Do you have any advice for incoming students?

Know what you want. When entering any type of medical major it is important to be passionate about the field because a lot of hard work will be needed when in the actual program. When you first get to OIT, get out there and meet new people. The school offers various programs to attend to give new students opportunities to meet people and get involved.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I like the intense nature of the classroom time.
StudentProfile.Biography:
I am the President of the ASME Student section at OIT Portland, and also a member of Sigma Alpha Pi.

After graduation I would like to Work in research and development to improve energy efficiencies. Specifically, the capturing and concentrating of thermal energy from the sun to power HVAC systems.

At OIT I like The intense nature of the class room time. There is no "fluff",as the lesson is presented. Secondly, Staff and Faculty, are focused on the providing the student with the tools to succeed.

My MET415 design project that required building an AC/DC power supply, converting a 6 wire stepper motor to 4 wire motor controller and writing the PLC program to automate the operation of the linear actuator. My MET 492 senior project, built with my team, a parabolic cylinder with dual axis tracking to follow the sun’s travel through the changes in day and seasons to capture thermal energy. This system has been able to produce hot water at a temperature of 140 degrees F. My Senior project is available through the OIT Library's Senior Project repository pilot project.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Graduated Doctor of Pharmacy program, OSU / OHSU 2013
StudentProfile.Biography:
Post-graduate program: Pharmacy (Pharm.D.) OSU / OHSU

Pharm.D. graduation year: 2013

What are you doing now, career-wise?

Currently, I work for CareOregon which is the largest Coordinated Care Organization in the State of Oregon. We serve roughly 200,000 Oregon Medicaid and Oregon Medicare members. Most of our members are low-income and in the Portland-Metro area. Lots of pharmacists work for CareOregon and we all specialize in different disease states and different sub-populations of people.

My specific patient-population are those with Advanced Illness, generally people who have end-stage disease (such as terminal cancer) or functional impairments (such as dementia). I see most of my patient’s in their homes and they are usually in my care for about one year before transitioning to hospice or passing away.

I enjoy helping my patients access, organize, and simplify their medication regimens. I also enjoy helping people manage their pain or other symptoms. I work closely with nurses, primary care providers, specialists and social workers to help keep these patients safe and comfortable at home. We also help patients clarify their goals of care and honor their choices.

Is there any other achievement or involvement that you'd like to share?

I finished my Post-doctoral training in 2016. Here is the specific project I completed as lead investigator.

Goeres LM, Gille A, Furuno JP, et al. Rural-urban differences in chronic disease and drug utilization in older Oregonians. J Rural Health. 2016;32(3):269–279

I have also been a co-author of several other published, peer-reviewed papers studying the health outcomes of medications like statins, beta blockers and other anti-hypertensives in older patients.

What is one thing that you really appreciated about our program at Oregon Tech?

I benefited from professors knowing who I was and what my career objectives were. I felt that through various projects and even some in-class instruction, I received an education that was customized to my interest in pharmacy, yet very well rounded.

At OIT, there was a partnership that happened between me as a student and the faculty; I felt like my triumphs were their success. I also appreciated the professors with clinical backgrounds which gave me a leg-up in a clinical professional school.

What is one piece of advice that you would give to a student in our program today?

It's always good to get A's but sometimes you learn more when you get a B.

Profile updated May 2017

StudentProfile.TeaserText: The combination of realistic business education and hands-on learning is what made me choose Oregon Tech...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

The combination of realistic business education and hands-on learning is what made me choose Oregon Tech. Out of all the universities in Oregon, Oregon Tech was the one to give me confidence in knowing that I can learn about the skills needed in a changing business world and put those skills into practice at the same time.

What do you like most about your major?

I love that I have the best of both worlds in terms of Management and Accounting. My major allows me to refine my skills in different areas of Accounting as well as learn about different components essential to running an organization successfully. Those other components so far have been Information Technology, Communications, and Management.

What would be your dream job in your major?

My dream job in my major would be one where I can interact with other business professionals at an executive level as well as work with the finances and accounting that go in to the operation of an organization or company. Summarized into one title, that would be a Chief Financial Officer.

What’s your favorite thing to do off campus?

I am a part of a young adult group called “The 120” at Klamath Christian Center. A significant portion of the group is made up of OIT students, and I love being able to come together with them outside of school. I consider The 120 a second family and enjoy activities with them from getting ice cream to hiking around Moore Park.

What’s your most memorable moment on campus?

My most memorable moment on campus was when I had a great conversation with my Argumentative Writing Professor. He challenged me to look beyond the usual question of “how does this class apply to my major,” and instead ask the question, “how does my major apply to this class?” In just that single difference I realized the importance of developing myself as a well-rounded business student rather than just an Accounting major.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: The education I received at OIT prepared me for the challenges of medical school and further education...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Post-graduate program: Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine, Rocky Vista University, Parker, CO

D.O. graduation year: 2012

What are you doing now, career-wise (or what do you plan to do after graduating)?

Right now I’m currently what is called a general medical officer (GMO) with a Marine unit in Camp Pendleton, CA. I completed a family medicine internship in 2013 and then started my GMO tour. So far I have been in training in various places around the country and have completed a deployment to Okinawa, Japan where we did exercises in mainland Japan and South Korea.

I will be applying for a residency in Radiology this year with the U.S. Navy. They have training programs in San Diego, CA, Portsmouth, VA, and Bethesda, MD. My first choice for this very competitive specialty is San Diego, CA.

Is there any other achievement or involvement that you’d like to share?

I graduated in the Top 10% of my class in 2012, as well as received an award for being the top military student during the 2011-2012 school year. Also, I was inducted into the Sigma Sigma Phi National Osteopathic Honor Society.

I have a publication that has been accepted to the Journal of Thoracic Imaging which will appear in the November 2014 issue.
Moullet, P & Mann, H Beak sign. Journal of Thoracic Imaging.

What is one thing that you really appreciated about our program at Oregon Tech?

I feel like it has been said before, but the one thing I admired and appreciated most about the Biology program at OIT was the low student to teacher ratio. This enabled very close support and mentorship from the professors to enable full scope and highly personalized education. It very much reminds me of the book David and Goliath by Malcolm Gladwell where he discusses how going to a lesser known school with a good educational program produces as good as or better students more often than very well known schools with high academic prestige.

What is one piece of advice that you would give to a student in our program today?

Plan early on where you would like to be in the future and don’t let the fact that you are at a small program let others deviate you from where you want to be. The education I received at OIT prepared me for the challenges of medical school and further education with, if not, better than any other school.

 

Profile updated Sept 2014

StudentProfile.TeaserText: When comparing my undergraduate experience to my colleagues in dental school and to my two years spent at OSU, I was really proud to have graduated from OIT...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Post-graduate program: Doctor of Dental Medicine (DMD) at Oregon Health & Sciences University (OHSU) in Portland, OR

D.M.D. graduation year: 2014

What are you doing now, career-wise?

As a new dentist, I am working in two very different sectors of the dental world to gain more experience serving various patient populations. I am working as an associate in a private practice in Eugene, OR, and for Willamette Dental in Corvallis, OR. I am currently learning a lot from both jobs and growing in my career!

What is one thing that you really appreciated about our program at Oregon Tech?

When comparing my undergraduate experience to my colleagues in dental school and to my two years spent at OSU, I was really proud to have graduated from OIT. The small class sizes truly enhanced my learning experience. For example, at OIT, there were 12 students in my Anatomy and Physiology course. We were provided four fresh cadavers to learn from via dissection. Not one of my classmates at OHSU had this experience. Most schools don’t allow undergraduate students to dissect the cadavers. They were forced to learn from previous dissections that were difficult to preserve. I learned so much about the human body by doing the dissections myself.

Also, the professors in the Biology and Health Sciences program are incredible! I took classes from Dr. Clark, Dr. O’Shaughnessy, and Dr. Usher. Each of these individuals has an impressive background, is an excellent teacher, and truly cares about their students.

What is one piece of advice that you would give to a student in our program today?

Post-graduate medical programs want well-rounded individuals. Of course, focus on your studies, but also find other things that you are passionate about, such as sports, community service, humanitarian trips, research, clubs or hobbies! Don’t let your career choice be your entire life.

 

Profile updated Sept 2014

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I will be awarded a DMD and return to practice dentistry somewhere in rural Oregon...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Post-graduate program: Doctor of Dental Medicine (DMD) at Midwestern University – College of Dental Medicine in Glendale, AZ

D.M.D. graduation year: 2015

What are you doing now, career-wise (or what do you plan to do after graduating)?

I’m currently a Staff Dentist at Umpqua Community Health Center in Roseburg, Oregon. Quite a few of my dental classmates would talk about how much money they were going to make as dentists after graduation. As for myself, a career in public health was always the goal. I was drawn to healthcare as a way to make my mark on the world and "do good". Now that I am a dentist, I help people all day long, many who have never had access to dentistry on a regular basis, if ever. I feel so fortunate to have landed my dream job!

Is there any other achievement or involvement that you’d like to share?

I’m really proud to have been awarded a National Health Service Corp Scholarship. As an NHSC Scholar, I will spend at least my first four years after dental school working with underserved populations. Sure, it has helped alleviate a large portion of my dental school debt, but more importantly, it has allowed me to take a career path that I would have been unable to reasonably consider without their support. I would also like to say to those other “non-traditional students” out there, it’s never too late to try and change your life!

What is one thing that you really appreciated about our program at Oregon Tech?

Many people cite the small class size and great instructors at OIT as instrumental to their success, and I couldn't agree more. Ultimately though, if you want to pursue a graduate degree, a major factor is the overall quality of preparation for program prerequisites, admissions tests, and grad school coursework that makes the difference. I've honestly lost track of how many times I've paused in the last few years and thought, "Yeah, I learned that at OIT!"

What is one piece of advice that you would give to a student in our program today?

Work hard and learn to study effectively. The difference in required effort between undergrad and grad school is immense.

 

Profile updated May 2017

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I appreciated the small class sizes and the easy access to the professors...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Post-graduate program: Doctor of osteopathic medicine (DO), Western University of Health Sciences-Northwest (Lebanon)

D.O. graduation year (expected): 2017

What are you doing now, career-wise (or what do you plan to do after graduating)?

Currently, I am attending medical school at Western University of Health Sciences at the Northwest Campus. After graduating, I plan on practicing as either a primary care physician, a critical care specialist, or a hospitalist. No matter which specialty I go into; however, I do plan on integrating holistic medicine into the way I practice.

What is one thing that you really appreciated about our program at Oregon Tech?

My undergraduate education at Oregon Tech was spectacular. I’m not just saying that because I was asked to write this Alumni spotlight- I really don’t think I could’ve received a better education. The quality of the faculty was outstanding and the learning environment was phenomenal. I appreciated the small class sizes and the easy access to the professors. There were many times I sat at the tables on the second floor of Dow when a professor came and sat down with me and asked if I had any questions; I don’t know any other school where that occurs. I am more than satisfied with the education I received at Oregon Tech and I owe it all to the professors (with a special thanks to Dr. Usher, Dr. Clark, Dr. Swisher, and Dr. O).

What is one piece of advice that you would give to a student in our program today?

I’m assuming that the students in the Health Sciences/Biology degree are all wanting to go into the healthcare field, so this advice is for all the pre-health provider students. First off, take all of your classes seriously; the information comes up again in medical school, only much more in depth. Secondly, make sure that you are going into the health profession for genuine reasons. Medical school is hard and extremely stressful. And, at the end of your medical education you will be given the power to change the lives of human beings. If you don’t want to be a doctor/dentist, etc. with everything you have, then I recommend another profession. Lastly, if you know that being a doctor is in your blood, then don’t give up. If you are denied acceptance into medical school, then try again. You WILL get in.

 

Profile updated Oct 2014

StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech because the Renewable Energy Program is highly recognized around the world. Before coming here, I searched and found this to be one of the best schools for this major.

Why did you choose your major?

Oman has so many natural resources for renewable energy and I will use my education to help my country develop this field. I’m proud and excited to be the first Omani woman in renewable energy in my country. Renewable Energy has a great future!

What do you plan to do with your degree?

I will continue my education in the graduate program in project management, and plan to work in one of Oman’s solar energy companies. And hopefully own my company in the future!

What would you like us to know about you?

I am originally Omani, but I was born in the U.S. My favorite color is blue. I love traveling and have visited: Arabian Gulf countries, Tanzania, Spain, France, Italy, Switzerland, Monaco, and around the United States!

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I chose Oregon Tech because of how highly acclaimed their Computer Engineering Department is...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech because of how highly acclaimed their Computer Engineering Department is. I researched colleges in the US before coming here and I believe I couldn't have made a better choice!

Why did you choose your major?

Programming has been an interest of mine for quite some time. I never pursued it in anyway until I came to Oregon Tech. Coding is fun and the feeling you get when creating something out of nothing is indescribable.

What do you plan to do with your degree?

Perhaps get some work experience here in the United States and then go back to Saudi Arabia to work and be with my family.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: The greatest aspect of online classrooms is the flexibility of hours...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech Online?

After researching several degree completion programs, Oregon Tech’s profile fit what I was looking for. The cost was affordable and the flexibility of the online coursework allowed me to work and go to school at the same time. I was also able to take a semester off when I was preparing for my daughter’s wedding.

What do you like best about your major?

I love dental hygiene and have been a practicing hygienist for 24 years before entering the degree completion program at Oregon Tech. Dental Hygiene is a great career for anyone wanting to be in a healthcare profession. Hygienist’s don’t have to work full-time to make a decent living, so this is what attracted me to the profession because I wanted to be a homemaker and mother when I began my career. Furthering my education will allow me to look for other employment opportunities outside of clinical dental hygiene, like teaching, research, or public health.

What has been the greatest aspect of completing your degree online?

The greatest aspect of online classrooms is the flexibility of hours. The student gets to choose when they go to school. I most often did my coursework on my days off or on weekends. Occasionally, I would log on in the evenings after work, but it was nice knowing I didn't have to if I had other obligations.

What career do you hope to have after you graduate from Oregon Tech?

Now that I have my Bachelor’s degree I would like to enter a Master’s program so that I can become a dental hygiene professor. My professors at Oregon Tech were fantastic mentors and good examples of what college professors should be.

Do you have any advice for incoming students?

My advice for incoming students would be to plan on spending anywhere from 6-10 hours per week for coursework, and occasionally more if research papers are due. Additionally, talk with your advisor so that you can have a plan on how to approach your schedule. Have fun and enjoy learning in this wonderful format!

StudentProfile.TeaserText: The greatest aspect of completing my degree online is the freedom of working at my own pace...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech Online?

I have chosen Oregon Tech Online because of my busy schedule. I am working full-time and trying to finish my degree, and going to classes isn't always an option for me. Most of the classes I have to take are at times when I work, so it has been very difficult to take the classes that I need. Now that I am doing my degree online, I have the ability to take any class that I need and have it fit into my schedule.

What do you like best about your major?

I love that my major offers so many career opportunities. I know that when I leave Oregon Tech I will get a job that I will love, even if I change my mind a hundred times. I can choose to work at the hospital, the school district or even work for the state. The possibilities are endless.

What has been the greatest aspect of completing your degree online?

The greatest aspect of completing my degree online is the freedom of working at my own pace. I get to choose when I do homework and don’t have to worry about being to class on time or even getting dressed for the day. I can throw on my yoga pants, have a cup of coffee and get the same education.

What career do you hope to have after you graduate from Oregon Tech?

After graduating from Oregon Tech, I hope to have a career in either social work or in child psychology. My passion is working with children and I want to have a career that will give me an opportunity to help children in need.

Do you have any advice for incoming students?

My biggest advice for incoming students would have to be to manage your time well. It seems like a small task, but it is so very important. Being able to manage your social life, work and school will make everything so much easier. So plan out your week, make sure that you make time for all the things that you want to get done and stick to that plan.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I chose Oregon Tech Online because of the program’s esteemed reputation, realistic expectations and user-friendly appeal...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech Online?

I knew that the most effective way to earn my bachelor’s degree while working full time would be to enroll in an online program. I chose Oregon Tech Online because of the program’s esteemed reputation, realistic expectations and user-friendly appeal. Initially I was apprehensive about online schooling, having no prior experience with it, but from my first contact with Oregon Tech’s staff I felt reassured and gained confidence with the prospects of my success.

What do you like best about your major?

Throughout the progression of my courses, I was able to network with other students and developed a sense of comradery with other hygienists also working towards their bachelor’s degree. It was really fun getting to know other students in my same profession whose aims were similar to mine in the development of their education and career.

What has been the greatest aspect of completing your degree online?

I loved being able to do the online coursework at my own pace and on my own timeline. Doing courses online allowed me the flexibility to complete projects while I traveled and worked from my laptop anywhere in the world. I was able to do schoolwork while in Hawaii, Las Vegas and even Mexico!

What career do you hope to have after you graduate from Oregon Tech?

Achieving my bachelor’s degree allows me to further my career as a dental hygienist and has helped me to become an adjunct clinical faculty member at Oregon Tech’s dental hygiene program in Salem. In completing this new facet of my education, I feel more empowered and positive about my future as a dental hygienist and feel that many doors for my future are open. Attaining my bachelor’s degree has now even given me the hope of looking forward to completing a master’s degree- before I would have never dreamed this possible!

Do you have any advice for incoming students?

My advice for other students would be to take one day at a time, persevere and to never give up. The program can be challenging at times, however, it is said that anything worth achieving will be difficult to overcome. The amazing and gratifying feeling of graduating will be worth the hours spent studying, hard work and dedication to achieving a higher education.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I chose Oregon Tech for its great reputation and choices in degree programs...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech Online?

I chose Oregon Tech for its great reputation and choices in degree programs.

What do you like best about your major?

I selected Applied Psychology as it provides a variety of career opportunities that I am interested in.

What has been the greatest aspect of completing your degree online?

The best part of completing my degree online is the flexibility to make my own schedule. Being able to schedule classes and tests with my work schedule has made continuing my education possible.

What career do you hope to have after you graduate from Oregon Tech?

I would like to continue my education by obtaining my master's degree and become an Occupational therapist.

Do you have any advice for incoming students?

My advice for incoming students would be to keep a regular schedule for study times that are compatible with their life.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Being an athlete, working full time, and now being married, online was the best option...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech Online?

Being an athlete, working full time, and now being married, online was the best option for me because I can take it with me wherever I go. Putting myself through college requires me working full-time, so being able to do my homework during a down time at work was beneficial for me. Also being an athlete, I am able to play and coach as well as doing school on the road.

What do you like best about your major?

I love that I have awesome teachers who are so devoted to psychology that it makes it so easy to learn. I love that I am able to learn just as much online as I was in the classroom and I still feel like I am in lectures, but I am able to do it on my own time.

What has been the greatest aspect of completing your degree online?

I am able to work at my own pace from wherever I want. I am also able to still communicate with teachers and students on the online discussion boards as if I were in class. I am also able to work, travel, play soccer, but also do my schooling. I also love the online videos, blogs, and research I am able to do from my computer.

What career do you hope to have after you graduate from Oregon Tech?

I hope to be a sports psychologist so that I am able to to continue my love for sports but also do my newfound love which is psychology.

Do you have any advice for incoming students?

My advice would be to not be afraid to email teachers or students if you do not understand something. Also, make sure you check due dates because they are not verbalized to you as they are in the classroom. Also, interacting with students in the discussion section of the class allows you to interact as if you were face to face and provides so many new thoughts and ideas about the topics being discussed.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: The flexibility in project selection and course topics grants the opportunity for...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech due to its diversity in renewable energy topics. This school is unique in that a student can generate specific skills to their interest. The flexibility in project selection and course topics grants the opportunity for a very diverse portfolio.

What do you like best about your major?

Going forward I am the most excited to see how the Graduate REE program develops and the tremendous influence our graduates will have on the energy industry at large.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Oregon Tech has a unique degree program that perfectly matches with my career aspiration...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

Oregon Tech has a unique degree program that perfectly matches with my career aspiration: Master’s in Electrical and Renewable Energy Engineering (MSREE).

What do you like best about your major?

I really like some sequences in the MSREE program:

  1. Battery and Energy Storage: the courses give precious knowledge in the hot topic of energy storage. Now, I truly understand the chemical reactions inside batteries, how batteries degrade over time, pros and cons of various types of energy storage (fuel cells, batteries, fly wheels, etc.).
  2. Solar Energy: as a result of taking these courses, I deeply understand the solar industry from how a solar cells works, to manufacturing, applications, and design trade-offs of a solar photovoltaic system.
  3. Research Method and Innovation: I can finally draft a patent application myself after taking the first course in the sequence.

I have to say that these sequences gave me indispensable knowledge for my future career.

What would be your dream job in your major?

It is one that not only makes me rich, but is also inspirational and, most importantly, has great, positive contributions to the world. With these criteria in mind, my dream job is, undoubtedly, a job in the renewable energy industry.

What’s your most memorable moment on campus?

It was when we built a three-phase inverter, staying up late at night in the lab, putting in tons of effort, and seeing it work beautifully.

What’s your favorite thing to do off campus?

I like to go to vegan restaurants, meet with vegan people, and enjoy the group’s activities. No doubt, Portland is the most vegan friendly city in the world.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: When I graduate I will have acquired skills that are needed in every country and will always be needed...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I initially chose Oregon Tech because I have extended family who live here and I am close to home. I then wanted a town that provided a small university and a community college to finish my prerequisites and then transfer; Klamath Falls offered both. Lastly, I heard nothing but glowing remarks about the civil engineering department at Oregon Tech from students, potential future employers, and faculty alike. I couldn't deny the fact that Oregon Tech seemed to have nothing but positive feedback and I can now attest to the accuracy of these statements.

What do you like most about your major?

I like that with my degree I will have the opportunity to travel the world and work across many different cultures. When I graduate I will have acquired skills that are needed in every country and will always be needed. Additionally, one of the simplest reasons I love civil engineering and I decided on this major is because I get to use math to solve real world problems and math really simply makes life fun.

What would be your dream job in your major?

I am going to college for a degree in civil engineering with a focus in water resources for a very specific purpose. I want to build wells and work in bringing clean water to communities in developing nations. I foresee myself obtaining a master's degree and then going overseas to work with a company like Black and Veatch, under a professional engineer for three years until I can take the PE exam and receive a license.

What’s your favorite thing to do off campus?

Outside of school and on-campus activities I love to do anything outdoors with my friends and family. I enjoy bike riding, running, tennis, ultimate frisbee, hiking, and practically anything else that involves exercise and sunshine! In down time I love to read for hours, though I don't find time for this except in the summers.

What’s your most memorable moment on campus?

I don't think I can single out just one moment, but I think collectively I have most enjoyed being a part of Christian Fellowship and all of the friendships I have built during Friday nights, road trips, and serving together. I have built some of the closest friendships during these short 9 months in this group. Additionally being involved in other clubs on campus like Engineers Without Borders and Concrete Canoe, and going to campus events like the Golden Gate Bridge Presentation have enriched my learning experience, making me a more well-rounded student.

Above photo courtesy of Miss Klamath County-Miss City of Sunshine Organization

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I think that general ultrasound best suits my skill set and I love the science behind ultrasound...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

They have an amazing Medical Imaging Program and I was given the opportunity to be a part of the track and field team. I've participated in athletics my whole life and it would a hard transition into college without them.

What do you like most about your major?

I feel that Pre-MIT really prepares students for the challenging courses they will be taking once they're in the programs. They also take the time to make sure that each student is pursuing the right modality and they find one that best suits them.

What would be your dream job in your major?

I would love to be a Diagnostic Medical Sonographer in a small hospital or clinic. I think that general ultrasound best suits my skill set and I love the science behind ultrasound.

What’s your favorite thing to do off campus?

My favorite thing to do off campus is visit Crater Lake. It's always really refreshing to get of our town and marvel at the incredible lake.

What’s your most memorable moment on campus?

My most memorable moment of campus was joining a last minute game of capture the flag at ten o'clock on a school night. My friends and I got really competitive and It was a perfect stress reliever.

Above photo courtesy of Miss Klamath County-Miss City of Sunshine Organization

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I love that this school, and my major in particular, provide...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I originally came to Oregon Tech to take advantage of the accredited renewable energy engineering program. It turned out that engineering wasn't for me after all, so I spoke to Dan Peterson about switching over to communication studies. He was able to utilize all my math and science credits toward my focus sequence electives in my new major, and I am ridiculously happy in this venture!

What do you like most about your major?

I love how flexible the degree is in terms of coursework availability. The classes are fun, applicable, and small. The professors are incredibly approachable, and not only are you learning from experts in the academic field, but they have extensive industry experience as well. But the best part is how devoted the professors are to their students and will do whatever they can to help them succeed.

What would be your dream job in your major?

It's difficult to pin down one thing that I could with this major, since it is so versatile, but that's why I chose it. I love that I have set up my major to ensure that I can do a wide variety of things over the years including mediation, document design (graphic), technical writing, human resources, or organizational communication. I could also move on to graduate school in law, psychology, or even public relations. Right now, I would like to gain a reputation as a mediator by starting in a human resources department of a large corporation, since they tend to handle dispute resolution in-house.

What’s your favorite thing to do off campus?

More than anything, I like to hang out with my two dogs! I enjoy traveling, cooking, spending time with friends, and exploring the basin. I like to meet new people, go on new adventures, and try new recipes, but I also like to stay home and binge watch Hulu!

What’s your most memorable moment within your school career?

I would never be able to pin down just one memorable moment. I love that this school, and my major in particular, provide the perfect environment to make amazing friendships that I know will last a lifetime. The people I have met here are such supportive, wise, fun, and intelligent individuals, and I truly believe that the same kind of experience could not be had at any other university.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I love the faculty. I know I could go to any of my professors...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I learn a lot better in smaller classrooms, so that was a really important factor for me. Then when I visited and toured the campus everyone I met was really welcoming, I didn’t just feel like a number and everything clicked and it felt right.

What do you like most about your major?

I love the faculty. I know I could go to any of my professors and get their advice about anything, even unrelated to school.

What would be your dream job in your major?

I have my dream job. I was lucky enough to get three internships before I graduate and test out several areas of civil engineering and find what I’m passionate about. I interned with Kiewit Infrastructure Engineers in Denver last summer and loved it so much I’m going back! I get to work on multibillion dollar design-build projects, where I optimize design of roadways to help the company win jobs, and I wouldn’t want to do anything different!

What activities are you involved in on campus?

I am an ambassador in the Admissions Office, I’m president of the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE), I’m involved with the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) and Concrete Canoe (past concrete canoe captain), I’m a Women in Transportation Seminar (WTS) scholarship recipient- as such, I get to travel to Austin, Texas for the WTS Annual Conference in May, I was a New Student Orientation group leader and I’m also project manager for my senior project group, working on the “Downtown for People” Blue Zones project in Klamath Falls.

What’s your favorite thing to do off campus?

I love snowboarding! The Outdoor Program has great trips for really reduced prices and I try to go on as many as possible!

What’s your most memorable moment within your school career?

There are so many! Probably the most memorable moment was when I got to travel to Washington DC for the Transportation Research Board Annual Meeting. While we were there we got to tour the Capitol and meet our Oregon Representative, Greg Walden. He was really great to talk with and was genuinely interested in our projects and our futures.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I chose Oregon Tech because it gave me the opportunity...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech because it gave me the opportunity to pursue something that I loved, which is the environment, and be able to make a difference with the education. Also while getting the chance to further my sports career playing volleyball here at Oregon Tech.

What do you like most about your major?

I like that it is so hands-on. We get to go on field trips a lot, and be able to apply the skills we learn in class to the real-world environment. I also like the diversity and multiple emphasizes that can be applied to the major, such as fire ecology, watershed, botany, wildlife ecology, and many others.

What would be your dream job in your major?

My dream job would be to be a Hydrologist. A Hydrologist is the study of the movement, distribution, and quality of earth’s water systems and sustainability. I’ve always been interested in conservation and water quality, and this is the perfect job to apply both.

What’s your favorite thing to do off campus?

I enjoy to be outside most of the time. I like hikes, and when I go home I like to ride my horses. I play basketball with my dad and brothers, and play in tournaments. I also enjoy getting to play with my young niece and nephew. Basically anything where I get to be with my family is the best time.

What’s your most memorable moment within your school career?

One of my most memorable moments thus far has been when I got to wade in the Link River for one of my environmental labs. I got wear the big wading boots that came up to my chest and we got to collect macroinvertebrates and then got to analyze them all and classify them. By seeing what specimens we found, we could determine the quality of the water. This was just something that I enjoyed the most.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: One thing I love about software is how many different types of things I can do with it...
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I'm a first generation college student, so one of my main concerns for choosing a college was how easy it would be to find a job right after graduation. I wanted to make sure that my investment would be worth it. Oregon Tech is the only school in the Pacific Northwest that offers a 96% employment rate within 6 months of graduating with my degree. I felt I could stay close to home with the comfort of knowing that I could find a job.

What do you like most about your major?

When I took my first programming class my first term in CSET, my professors talked about the "CSET Family." I had no idea what they were talking about until the middle of the term when I was struggling with the difficult concepts and heavy workload. I found that I can ask any student or professor for help and they will help if they can. Now that I'm a junior, other students come to me for help with their coursework. My favorite part my major is that the "CSET Family" pushes me to the limit, and a little farther, to make sure I will be a programmer prepared for any challenge, but they also provide support when it is needed.

What would be your dream job in your major?

One thing I love about software is how many different types of things I can do with it. I could make websites or write the code that controls a pacemaker. My dream is to make a big impact. I'm currently in a startup company that will provide small farmers with access to high technology by creating an inexpensive robotics kit to fit the equipment they already own. The kit will automate the farming equipment and collect field diagnostics to provide live updates for resource management.
