You’d be amazed at how such a small town can really make you feel at home.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: One of the figures that stood out to me when looking at schools was the return on investment, and Oregon Tech excels in that field.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech because I saw great value. One of the figures that stood out to me when looking at schools was the return on investment, and Oregon Tech excels in that field.

What do you like most about your program?

What I like about the business management program is hands-on learning. On my first day of my first marketing class we were already creating content that would actually be posted to the school’s social media. I love marketing because it combines creative thinking with data and statistics, two things I enjoy.

What would be your dream job?

My dream job would be to work on a professional sports team’s marketing team. I have always been drawn to sports and would enjoy working around them. Working for any professional sports teams in Portland would be as good as it gets.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

I really enjoyed principles of management because we got to dive into the history of some of the greatest leaders to ever live. Their stories were inspiring to say the least. I also enjoyed my databases class that has taught us how to create useful databases. It is a very applicable skill to be able to build a database. I can see it being very useful, especially if I ever get involved in a small business.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

I wish everyone knew how beautiful it is here. There is a sunset almost every night, the rolling hills are beautiful, and the view of Klamath Lake from campus is amazing. And when the snow falls and covers everything in a blanket of white, it’s a whole new beautiful.

Are you involved on campus? If so, how?  

I work for the Men’s Basketball team and with the athletics department as a whole. I create graphics for the athletics website, take photos at games, and help run social media. I go to almost every home sporting event. These jobs have also given me many opportunities to design. I designed the home basketball game ticket stubs, the game day program cover, and many of the animations that plat on the video boards during games.

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

Get involved in some campus activity. It’s the best way to meet people and discover passions at the same time!

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I transferred in as a junior, but after the first year I feel very comfortable with all of my peers and professors.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Dean's and President's List, Softball 2017 All-Conference Honorable Mention,
2017 Gold Glove 

Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

(I am a junior college transfer student) I wanted to continue playing softball in college, but I wasn't going to continue playing if I couldn't find a school to play for that could meet my personal preferences as well as provide me with a great education. I visited OIT with my father. He was prepared to dislike it, I was more open, but post tour and adviser/coach meetings we both left convinced this was the place for me. 

What do you like most about your program?

I love how small it is, there's 37 of us! I transferred in as a junior, but after the first year I feel very comfortable with all of my peers and professors.  I get the opportunity to work on projects and personally work with local businesses that I wouldn't have had the opportunity to if our program had the same number of students as larger universities. 

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

Marketing jobs vary greatly so your impact can be seen in any aspect of the business world.  I want to be part of the reason a company grows and thrives, as well as sharing with the world a product/service that can impact their lives for good. 

What would be your dream job?

I would be part of the huge and intricate process of creating a Super Bowl ad.  The most watched event of the year with the most iconic commercials and I could say I was small part of it.  But, landing a career within content marketing is my goal. 

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

Social media marketing: I keep getting involved with social media projects and jobs. It was a great class to teach the marketing aspects of the platforms and it was very fun!

Business Graphic Design: I use Photoshop often, but I'm self-taught. This class taught me more about the program, as well as others within the Adobe Creative Suite for business projects such as making logos, brochures, and business cards. I like the classes that allow me to use my creativity! 

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

That we have a business department! And a really high quality one as well! We get drowned out by the engineers and health majors, but our business programs are producing quality and career ready graduates as well. 

Have you participated in any internships during your time at Oregon Tech? Did you gain valuable experience from them?

I had an internship over the summer with a small law firm back in Washington with the position of social media manager - that was interesting considering my lack of knowledge about law.  I also am working for Oregon Tech Alumni Association and creating a social media marketing plan, guide, and schedule.  I never really thought I'd be so involved in social media marketing.

Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation?

I do not currently have any positions lined up, but I have been looking online at potential positions available back home and I am excited to start applying.  I met a news reporter-anchor from the Western, WA news station, KOMO 4 News, here at Oregon Tech during an auction and they mentioned there is a social media position available at their station.

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

Don't run away from the little town and campus, the surrounding environment makes up for it such as the Lava Beds, waterfalls, hot springs, Crater Lake, hikes and trails, and a beautiful sunset everyday over Klamath Lake.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: We work a lot on real life projects, which is what really prepares us for the future.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I came to Oregon Tech because I really wanted to study abroad in the U.S. and play college basketball as well. Oregon Tech was the school that could give me the best combination of both. They offered the degree I wanted and have one of the best NAIA basketball programs.

What do you like most about your program?

I really enjoy the small class sizes. I also like that all the professors have work experience in the field and that it translates into how they teach the classes. We work a lot on real life projects, which is what really prepares us for the future. 

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

I mostly enjoy marketing classes. I like to come up with new ideas to improve things. Also, as I said before, we work on real life projects with local business, which in my opinion, it is the best way to learn.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

I think that something that is not advertised enough is that all professors have work experience in their respective fields. And that really makes a difference when it comes to prepare students for their professional future.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: At OIT, most classes teach in lecture and later the knowledge is applied in labs.
StudentProfile.Biography:
What drew you to Oregon Tech?

In 2012/2013 I was a foreign exchange student here in Klamath Falls. I really enjoyed my experience throughout the high school year here and decided I want to come back for college after finishing school in Germany. Many people I’ve met here in town always told me what an excellent school Oregon Tech is and especially the high hire rates right after graduation had me very interested. My goal has been and still is to become a permanent U.S. resident and I am convinced that OIT is the perfect fit to achieve my goal. 

What interests you most about your program? 

My Dad is a mechanical engineer which gave me many insights to his everyday work experiences. I generally loved the idea of becoming an engineer since my mind just works in an “engineers-way”. However I noticed the long hours my Dad spent in design in front of a screen and I didn’t like it. He also has co-workers who are manufacturing engineers and during a short two week internship I discovered that that’s what I want to do. Mainly because it’s a lot of hands-on problem solving which is also what Oregon Tech really focuses on teaching.  

What I find most impressive and also important is how many labs Oregon Tech offers. During my school time in Germany, teaching mainly involved textbooks and solving problems on paper. At OIT, most classes teach in lecture and later the knowledge is applied in labs. In my opinion, hands on experiences from labs are far more valuable than reading books because it prepares students for future jobs in a way nothing else could. 

What would be your dream job?

My dream job would be working as a manufacturing engineering in a small to medium sized company. The reason is that the work environment is much more personal, the responsibilities are broader and the everyday work changes constantly. 

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

My favorite classes at OIT so far were the CAD/Solid modeling classes and Numerical Controls, which is the introduction to CNC. I really enjoyed the fact that these classes provided a great picture of everyday tasks for a manufacturing engineer. Like I said earlier, I just really like hands-on experiences!

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

One thing Oregon Tech has taught me is that job-wise pretty much anything is possible. The most important thing is to get out there and start talking to companies. I was amazed how easy it really is to establish good connections this way, compared to what one might think before trying.

Are you involved on campus? If so, how? 

My first involvement was starting to work at the college union info-desk. What I really enjoy about it is how close I get to work with fellow students, staff and visitors. The job itself has taught me a lot about leadership, management, service orientation and campus itself. Over the last year I‘ve also joined the Baja racing team and I‘m helping the cheerleading team whenever I can. 

Have you participated in any internships or externships during your time at Oregon Tech? Did you gain valuable experience from them?

After my freshman year I got my first manufacturing engineering internship. Those 3 summer months in a small potato packing shed in Malin, OR really made me look forward to graduating and getting a job. Even though I didn’t have too many engineering classes throughout my freshman year, I learned many things that helped me with classes later on. After my sophomore year I was an intern for 3 months at a construction company which once again let me apply lots of coursework to real world experiences and I gained many skills.

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about attending Oregon Tech?

If you like outdoor activities such as hunting, fishing, hiking, off-roading or winter sports as much as I do, Oregon Tech is in the perfect location. It’s also important to mention that Oregon Techs classes aren’t easy, but the professors make sure students understand the material covered since that’s what’s most important to have a successful career straight after graduation. I would also like to mention that OIT doesn’t only teach you in your particular field of study, but also offers many very valuable opportunities to learn how to be more successful in job search etc.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I chose Oregon Tech because of the small classes and the high job placement rate.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech because of the small classes and the high job placement rate (getting a job right after graduation). I enjoy being surrounded by students who want to graduate college, instead of people who just want to party during college.

What do you like most about your program?

I love that my program is small. Being in the I.T. department I have the same classmates in almost all my classes. I enjoy the collaboration my classmates and I have with labs and non-major related classes.

What are your passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

I’m passionate about working with databases, whether it is building, creating, updating, and/or maintain data. I love to interpret data and give data meaning so businesses can find ways to grow and/or improve.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

Some of my favorite classes at Oregon Tech are my core classes. I love them because I learn valuable skills, I enjoy learning from my advisor and other classmates. Labs in my core class are fun for me, because having a small class means labs turn into group projects and students help one another. I enjoy the comradery my classmates and I have.

Are you involved on campus? If so, how?

My first year at Oregon Tech I ran Cross Country, Track & Field for Oregon Tech. Now I spend my winter term snowboarding with my friends in the Outdoor Program (O.P.) and occasionally go on the O.P.’s camping trips.

Have you participated in any internships or externships during your time at Oregon Tech? Did you gain valuable experience from them?

At first, I was not really planning on doing an internship, but my senior project had a summer internship that tied in with the project. So, I spent summer 2017 interning at Klamath Irrigation District collecting data and understanding the company’s workflow in order to build a database and web page for a water usage and tracking accountability system.  I have learned vital information from this ongoing experience. I gained a lot of technical confidence in myself, and validation/satisfaction I have chosen the correct major.

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

Try to make some friends in your core classes. Friends will help you pass your classes. If you are serious about graduating with a degree and wanting a job, then Oregon Tech would fit for you.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: The civil engineering program is such a good balance of classroom and practical work.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

My dad graduated from Oregon Tech with his civil engineering degree. I heard about the good program from him and many of the other OIT graduates who work at the Washington Department of Transportation. When I decided to pursue civil engineering, it was the only choice.

What do you like most about your program?

The civil engineering program is such a good balance of classroom and practical work. We are learning concepts and the theory behind engineering, but then we get to go out to the labs and put them right into practice. The work is challenging, but working on group projects or studying for the FE together creates a real sense of community among the students. The faculty are also the best on campus. They know their technical stuff, but are also interested in helping students succeed, whether that is academically, professionally, or personally.

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

As one of my professors put it, my passion is designing for “small-town America. “ I hope to develop creative solutions to American transportation issues, specifically in car-centric rural environments, that meet the local economic goals and match the community lifestyle. Because of my experience at WSDOT, I completely understand the importance that vehicles have, and will continue to have, in rural towns and hope to become skilled at meeting the needs of all types of users.

What would be your dream job?

Once I graduate, I hope to work for a private engineering firm in the Pacific Northwest that specializes in transportation planning and design. The previous six summers I have been interning with WSDOT, which has allowed me to determine areas that I like or do not like. This summer was spend on a bicycle transportation-planning seminar, which completely changed the emphasis of my study (and future career) to multimodal transportation solutions.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

The graduate level transportation courses are excellent! Each course has a large project that allows to me combine the technical and communication skills that I have been honing during my time here at Oregon Tech – the work is engaging and the end result something that I am extremely proud of.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

The small class sizes at Oregon Tech are awesome. They allow students the ability to get to know their fellow students and faculty. These connections are the ones that get students internships, jobs, officer positions, study abroad trips, opportunities that are not as widely available at large schools.

Are you involved on campus? If so, how?

I have held multiple officer positions for the ITE Student Chapter, which has been one of the highlights of my time at Oregon Tech. I want to pursue transportation design, so an entire club dedicated to my field was a natural place for me to get involved. There are a few other clubs and committees that I hold positions in, including OIT Christian Fellowship, the American Society of Civil Engineers Concrete Canoe Team, the Cornett Hall Architectural Committee, and the Engineering Honor Society.  Lastly, I served as the project manager for my senior project team, which did an Alternatives Analysis for the KID C-Flume Replacement Project in Klamath Falls.

Have you participated in any internships or externships during your time at Oregon Tech? Did you gain valuable experience from them?

As an intern, I worked in three offices with WSDOT over the course of six years, including program management, construction, and design. Though the work challenged me, it gave me an intimate knowledge of the highway design and construction process. The theoretical principles that I learn in school make more sense when I can connect them to my own construction and design experiences on the job site.

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

Get involved! I showed up to Oregon Tech with no intention of hanging out longer than necessary. I ended up signing up for the MSCE program because of the relationships I have established on campus. There is so much support available and clubs in your interest areas – life extends far beyond the classroom here.

Awards/accomplishments during your time at Oregon Tech?

2017 National Institute for Transportation and Communities (NITC) Outstanding Student of the Year (Receiving award at national conference in January)

2017 Sustainable Bicycle Transportation Seminar – three week course in Denmark, Sweden, and the Netherlands studying European bicycling infrastructure and policies

Project manager for seven-member team conducting an alternatives analysis for ten foot diameter siphon pipe

2015, 2016 & 2017 NITC Scholarship Recipient

2015, 2016 & 2017 Jesse Crabtree and Leo Ferroni Scholarship Recipient

2017 Oregon Section ITE Graduate Student Scholarship Recipient

2016 Oregon Section ITE Undergraduate Student Scholarship Recipient

2016 Women in Transportation Seminar Scholarship Recipient

2016 Coral Sales Scholarship Recipient

2016 Asphalt Pavement Association of Oregon Education Foundation Scholarship Recipient

2016 Richard H. Zbinden Scholarship Recipient

2016 Oregon Tech Alumni Scholarship Recipient

Head Research Assistant on NITC Research Project Vehicle Dynamics

Research Assistant on Multi-institutional NITC Research Project Rethinking Streets for Bikes

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I am so grateful for the small class sizes, and our close relationship to our instructors and classmates.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

Since high school I have been interested in the career specific programs that Oregon Tech has to offer. Oregon Tech is also close to my hometown, Medford, Oregon, which made the decision to go even easier.  After a campus visit and tour of the MIT programs, I knew it was the place for me.

What do you like most about your program?

I am so grateful for the small class sizes, and our close relationship to our instructors and classmates.  I love that every class I have taken since freshman year has been applicable to both my degree and future position.  It’s also exciting to be a part of a program that is so coveted nationwide.

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

I am excited to use my position to make people feel comforted and cared for, on what is possibly their worst day ever.  I believe this is something that a lot of people feel they don’t receive during their healthcare experience.  I am also looking forward to using ultrasound for prospective treatments currently in research such as, treating cancers and degenerative diseases like Alzheimer’s.

What would be your dream job?

Before I start my family, I think it would be amazing to use ultrasound to see the world and be a traveling sonographer in English speaking countries.  I would also like to continue my career in a women’s outpatient center as a breast sonographer. 

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

In my pre-MIT year I was blown away by the level of education I received in my biology lectures and labs.  Every single professor went above and beyond to make sure we were prepared for our prospective programs.  In the DMS program, the labs have been my favorite.  Being able to spend time scanning on state of the art equipment with professionals in the field truly sets Oregon Tech apart.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

I wish that high school students could know how beneficial going to a technical school over a state school really is.  Everyone that gets through Oregon Tech’s imaging programs will have high paying jobs as soon as they graduate.  I also wish students in the Northwest could know how highly respected an education at Oregon Tech is through an employer’s eyes.

Are you involved on campus? If so, how?

I am involved in the DMS Club at Oregon Tech.  It is an amazing opportunity to do fun things as a group within my program and really get to know my classmates.  We have the opportunity to raise money for charities we care about through events like bake sales, and garage sales.  We also volunteer in our community to help clean up the roads around campus.  I have also loved participating in intramural volleyball and the outdoor program’s ski trips.

Have you participated in any internships or externships during your time at Oregon Tech? Did you gain valuable experience from them?

I am looking forward to my externship at a hospital for my entire senior year.  I am so thankful that Oregon Tech gives medical imaging students the opportunity to work in the field while also working towards a degree.

Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation?

The imaging programs at Oregon Tech guarantee an amazing placement at a hospital, and most likely a job offer at that hospital the following year.

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

I wish that I would have made the decision to come to Oregon Tech sooner!

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I chose Oregon Tech because it was the perfect place for me to receive a great education with also the ability to be a part of the Track and Field team.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech because it was the perfect place for me to receive a great education with also the ability to be a part of the Track and Field team. The small class sizes and personable professors make OIT very unique and special.

What do you like most about your program?

I love that I’m surrounded by professors and faculty that are very knowledgeable and supportive of me as a student, athlete, and entrepreneur.

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

I love small business and have a passion to change the way people think about Klamath Falls and Southern Oregon. I see so many people come here to get there degree, complain about Klamath, then leave after graduation. I want to change this trend and use small business as a pathway to making the Klamath experience a more enjoyable experience.

What would be your dream job?

I am already living my dream job by owning my own business, Bulletproof Brewhouse. However, I would love to own a business that required me to travel the country and world. 

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

One of my favorite and most difficult was class was entrepreneurship. This class taught me so much about business as we were required to write a business plan for a fictional business. Not only did this class teach me a lot, but it was huge factor to the success of the opening of Bulletproof Brewhouse.

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

I would tell any perspective student looking at Oregon Tech to not listen to what people have to say about Klamath Falls or Oregon Tech. I would push them to make their own opinions and to be the change. Don’t get caught up living the status quo; stand up, dream big, and be the change.

Categories.string: Management, Entrepreneurship and Small Business Option

StudentProfile.TeaserText: At this point, there was no time to waste; Amanda started performing CPR. While waiting for paramedics to arrive she had performed 4 or 5 rounds of CPR.
StudentProfile.Biography:
It was an average October afternoon when Amanda and her friend decided to escape studying to go eat lunch at a local downtown restaurant. Amanda, a senior in the Respiratory Care program at Oregon Institute of Technology (Oregon Tech), had already accrued a well-round base of critical care knowledge learned from her course work and externships, which came in handy this October afternoon.

Amanda and a friend had just sat down to eat when they both heard a loud crash. “It sounded like the crash came from the back of the restaurant,” Amanda recalls. “I looked around and did not see anything.”

Amanda’s friend thought someone had fallen down in the back of the restaurant. As Amanda approached the area where the noise came from she found an individual lying on the floor, unresponsive. Familiar with situations such as this during her time working at hospitals, she immediately checked for a pulse.

“People were eating their lunch and not doing anything,” Amanda exclaimed”

After checking the individual for a pulse, Amanda continued examining the situation for any obvious clues why this individual was not breathing and had no pulse.

Amanda remembers thinking at the time, “[Their] head was slightly propped up and I didn’t know if they had hit their head or what had actually occurred.”

As Amanda remained on the floor she looked around to see if anyone had notified 911, but, “People were still eating their lunches. One of the waitresses finally came over [to me] and stated they would call 911.” 

At this point, there was no time to waste; Amanda started performing CPR. While waiting for paramedics to arrive she had performed 4 or 5 rounds of CPR.

“I am glad I knew what to do,” stated Amanda. “It wasn’t my first time giving CPR- I have had to do it in the hospital before.”

When the paramedics arrived, they took control of the situation and started performing CPR as they were boarding the individual into the ambulance.

“[The situation] was not how I pictured something like that happening,” Amanda explained.

Amanda is a graduate from Sprague High School in Salem, Oregon and currently at her externship at Providence in Medford, Oregon.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I like that I get the opportunity to put the theory into practice with the applied experience part of the degree.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech because I wanted to attend a college with both good professors and a lot of emphasis on applied experience. I transferred from a very large University in Norway where my classes were huge, so the small class sizes and professor involvement was a huge deciding factor for me. 

What do you like most about your program?

I like that I get the opportunity to put the theory into practice with the applied experience part of the degree. By getting to try out different jobs in the field of psychology I feel more confident that I have chosen the career that is right for me. Additionally, the professor involvement in my education is such a unique trait of Oregon Tech, and I feel like my professors really want me to succeed.

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

I am passionate about changing the process of integration of refugees, especially now that the refugee crisis is ongoing. I think that it is so important to take good care of the people who have lost everything, and are now coming to a completely new and unfamiliar place, so that they can become productive members of society. The exposure to new cultures is such an enrichment to our society, and we should treat it as such.

What would be your dream job?

My dream job would be to work with the integration of refugees in my home country. I have always been drawn to new cultures, and I feel like I could truly make a difference in people’s lives with this job. Working closely with a vulnerable group of people would require much of the knowledge, skills, and training I have attained during my time at Oregon Tech.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

My very first upper division class, Behavior Modification, was my absolute favorite class! Not only was the professor, Dr. Loukus, a very passionate and amazing teacher, the material was so interesting. I learned so much about the reason why people behave the way they do, and how to make people behave a certain way. This class has been very useful in my job as an employment coach with the JOBS program at Oregon Tech, and I highly recommend this class.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

I wish everyone knew about how awesome Campus Life is! I always feel so loved every time I step into that office, and people seem to genuinely care about how I am doing. The bird feeder is also located there, where there’s almost always free food available to all students. After getting involved with Campus Life I always have a place to go if I have a break between classes, need to study, or if I just want to hang out with some cool people.

Are you involved on campus? If so, how?

I am involved with the Psychology Club and Psi Chi, the psychology honors society, Campus Life, and the JOBS program. I just recently got involved with Campus Life, by working on the New Student Orientation Team over the summer. Being involved on campus, and especially with Campus Life, has made my experience at Oregon Tech so much more than just school. Oregon Tech has for me become a place of not only learning, but also a place where I am having lots of fun, and creating long-lasting friendships.

Have you participated in any internships or externships during your time at Oregon Tech? Did you gain valuable experience from them?

I participated in an externship in Norway, working as a manager for a large restaurant. I gained a lot of valuable experience from this, such as management, HR, administration, communication, evaluation, and other skills related to psychology. Getting to actually use the concepts and theories I learned in class in real life made me feel so much more ready for life after graduation.

Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation?

I know that I want to go to graduate school at some point, but the Master’s program I am interested in requires two years of experience post-graduation, so my plan is to work in my field for a few years before applying. I am moving to Norway with my husband only a few days after graduation, and am currently in the process of applying for jobs there and I have some interviews lined up. 

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

I want students to know that it is never too early to start looking for externships, and local part-time jobs related to their field of study. The sooner you get your foot in the door, the more experience you have when you graduate and are looking for a full-time job. Utilize all the resources campus has to offer, take advantage of the free gym, the health center, Campus Life, and all the workshops and events happening. But most importantly, have some fun!

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Being at Oregon Tech was being in this environment where you are constantly iterating on your work and striving toward your goals.
StudentProfile.Biography:
What did you like most about your time at Oregon Tech?

Being at Oregon Tech was being in this environment where you are constantly iterating on your work and striving toward your goals. I was always in this loop of solving problems and finding better ways to achieve the task at hand. You don’t realize it at the time, but being in a place like that pushes you to be better.

What did you like most about your profession?

Software Engineers are the rock stars of this generation. Not only are we paid extremely well, but we work in a fast-paced, cutting-edge profession where each day brings new challenges. This constant evolution is what drives me every day to be excited about the work I do.

How long after graduation did it take you to find a job?

I signed to IGT in February (4 months before graduation), and started work a month after graduation.

How do you feel your time at Oregon Tech prepared you for your current job/continuing studies?

While no program of study can prepare you for everything, Oregon Tech gave me the building blocks that I needed to be able to transition into a fairly complex role within the industry. The leadership positions that I held while at Oregon Tech gave me communication and problem solving skills I utilize on a daily basis. 

Do you maintain professional relationships with any of your professors?

Professionally I stay connected with my professors through LinkedIn and OIT alumni events here in Reno. Personally I’m friends with all of my past professors on Facebook. 

What advice would you give to a current student at Oregon Tech?

“Be the magic.” - Phil Howard. This holds true for just about anything in life. Don’t wait around and expect that things will be done for you. Go out and make them happen.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Oregon Tech gave me the opportunity to make some lifelong friends whom I still chat with them today and keep in touch regularly.
StudentProfile.Biography:
What did you like most about your time at Oregon Tech?

Oregon Tech gave me the opportunity to make some lifelong friends whom I still chat with today and keep in touch regularly. 

What do you like most about your profession?

I love the autonomy that I have. I work in several intensive care units, here at Children's, and every day we interact with different types/combinations of disease processes and utilize different ventilator strategies and I love that I am responsible for those ventilators and the changes that are made. We are a teaching hospital, so we round as a team, which consists of the attending, fellow, resident, RN and RT and we are the experts on our patients that need respiratory assistance, so we are often asked for our recommendation, as we are the expert in our field. 

How long after graduation did it take you to find a job?

I worked at Asante Rogue Regional coinciding with graduation, so it did not take any time at all. Once I moved to Massachusetts, it took about 6 weeks to get my license and about 3 months to find a job. During this time, I had several interviews but the hiring process was long. I interviewed at Children's in July and my official start date was not until the beginning of October. My advice is to have patience; good things will come!

How do you feel your time at Oregon Tech prepared you for your current job?

All those blood gas classes... you need them! All those long hours going over ventilators... you NEED them. We are the experts on the respiratory status of our patients and when they are on assisted ventilation, those countless hours studying over the waveforms, the modes and why you would use them, are essential in our daily work. 

Is there anything you wish you would have done during your time at Oregon Tech that you didn’t?

I wish I would have participated in some of the on-campus groups/activities more. I made some great friends within the program, but I think I could have expanded that network even more, if I had spared a few more hours to other activities on campus. 

What advice would you give to a current Respiratory Care student at Oregon Tech?

Do not be afraid to apply anywhere and everywhere. I knew I was moving to Boston and I wanted to work at Boston Children's Hospital. It was an ambitious goal, I had only worked at Asante Rogue Regional as a therapist for 7 months, and graduated from OIT one week prior to starting the trek across America. I applied everywhere that had an opening. While the interview process was grueling, I was beyond ecstatic that I was going to be a respiratory therapist at Boston Children's Hospital. I have worked here two years now and I am starting the process for a promotion to respiratory therapist II.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: You get a lot more one-on-one with your professors and it is easier to get hands on experience with less students.
StudentProfile.Biography:
What did you like most about your time at Oregon Tech?

I think it is a huge bonus that the class sizes in my program are small. You get a lot more one-on-one with your professors and it is easier to get hands on experience with less students.

What do you like most about your profession?

There are many qualities that I admire about the respiratory field, for one, the versatility of this career is exciting. This career path has so many different avenues that you can take. You can specialize and work in the NICU or the ICU, or the ED, or pulmonary rehab, to just name a few, it just depends upon what you are passionate about. I have enjoyed working in the ED during my rotations, I like the challenges that come through the doors. I am looking forward to being a part of an extra corporeal membrane oxygenation team in the future. This is another area that respiratory therapists can be a part of, which I am interested in.

How long after graduation did it take you to find a job?

While I am still pursuing my degree, I was able to get a job as an ECG/Respiratory tech at Asante Rogue Regional Medical Center, and through this job opportunity I have been able to gain valuable hands on learning in my intended field of work.

I have not graduated with my degree yet, but I have found the hospital I will work at once I graduate and pass my boards.

Did you participate in any externships during your time at Oregon Tech?

As a respiratory therapy student at OIT, I have done rotations at three hospitals so far (Sky Lakes, Rogue, and Providence). I am looking forward to going to other hospitals for my upcoming terms.

I also participated in Respiratory Club events. I was the VP of the RCP club, so I had the pleasure of helping organize a group of walkers for a CF fundraiser walk in Sacramento, California. The club was a positive experience during my time at OIT. The club did many fundraisers and events. As an RT student I also did a smoking cessation talk at a local high school and I was able to be a part of the health fair/potato festival in Merrill.

How do you feel your time at Oregon Tech prepared you for your current job?

My current job is a tech at RRMC, and OIT had prepared me greatly for this job. In the job I currently hold, I was equipped with the basics from courses I took at OIT in my program. I was also able to use a few of my professors as professional references when I applied for the position.  

OIT is also equipping me to have a successful career as a respiratory therapist after graduation. In the program we take practice board exams every term, starting the spring term of junior year, and this is to help prepare us for the real boards. Taking the practice exams allows me to see where my strengths and weaknesses are currently, and it highlights where I need to focus my current studies to be successful in passing the boards.

Is there anything you wish you would have done during your time at Oregon Tech that you didn’t?

I wish I had attended more sports games. I only attended a few games towards the end of my junior year, but the games that I did attend with my friends were great experiences. Now that I am in my last year, I have moved to Medford to be closer to my hospital rotations, so I no longer have the option to just decide to go to a game last minute.

What advice would you give to a current Respiratory Care student at Oregon Tech?

Form a study group right away! Honestly, it is so helpful to have one of your peers explain a concept to you if you do not understand it in class. All of the professors are knowledgeable and willing to meet with you outside of class to help you succeed, but it is so important to have a study group of people who will hold you accountable. And just have fun, respiratory therapy is such an exciting career path.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: This program prepares students to tackle real-life issues and situations.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I have a passion for renewable energy. Oregon Tech is the first school in North America to offer degrees dedicated to renewable energy engineering. Also, I had heard about how beautiful Oregon is and I wanted to explore Oregon's nature.  

What do you like most about your program?

I like the focus on key renewable energy topics such as solar power, energy storage and other topics. Also, program prepares students to tackle real-life issues and situations. I also like the close interaction between students and professors. 

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

Applying renewable energy technologies has been hampered by cost issues and political considerations. I would like to see prices fall down enough for renewable energy technologies to be even more competitive in the energy market. I would also like to see a political atmosphere that is more embracing to renewable energy in my county, Egypt, and around the world.

What would be your dream job?

Minister of Electricity and Renewable Energy in Egypt.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

I liked the solar sequence very much. I acquired a lot of valuable information on solar energy and photovoltaics. 

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

We have advanced equipment for manufacturing and testing of photovoltaic panels and batteries.

Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation?

I would like to have a job in solar industry. At some point down the road I would like to enroll in a PhD program related to energy and/or sustainability.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I love the sense of community present in the class cohort and with the professors; we help each other, cheer on each other's successes, and the professor’s exhibit a true joy in teaching.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

Oregon Tech came highly recommended to me by a professor at my community college. After researching the programs offered here, the graduate employment statistics (high rates), and class sizes (small), it felt like a good fit. Oregon Tech provides the kind of learning environment and opportunities to its students that I was looking for.

What do you like most about your program?

I love the sense of community present in the class cohort and with the professors; we help each other, cheer on each other's successes, and the professor’s exhibit a true joy in teaching. There is a distinct sense that the goal is for us all to succeed, and it's wonderful when everyone is excelling. The program also celebrates intelligence, curiosity, discovery, and general geek status, which is a joyful experience.

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

There is need for enhancement of the relationship between the medical laboratory and other healthcare professionals. Often, whichever program one is enrolled in, there is little time for education about the realities and demands of other roles in the healthcare team. A little education and communication for both inside and out of the lab can make a remarkable difference in the expectations and relations on either side. 

What would be your dream job?

My dream job would be to work in a specialization that I am excited about and where I can use my skill-set do the most benefit for patients. I am also interested in entering teaching one day, in a program such as mine, to help the next generation of laboratory scientists. 

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

Choosing a short list of favorite classes is difficult; the classes I have taken at Oregon Tech have been pertinent, relevant, and exciting. Of the classes that I took to prepare for entry into my program: microbiology was my first real glimpse into the possibilities of medical laboratory science, immunology is a fascinating subject with many facets, and the study of genetics has the potential for far-reaching impacts for patients. Now that I am in the program, all the classes I am taking are geared towards the medical laboratory science profession and as such, are highly specific to my future career. Each class is enjoyable, but the laboratory portion of clinical immunology and infectious serology is a new adventure every week with a vast array of assays to run.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

Prospective students should know that Oregon Tech offers professors that are deeply invested in their students that will go above and beyond to help students and to support them, and are also excited to be teaching. All students should know that communication is highly valued at Oregon Tech; there are resources available to students that need help whether it's counseling, tutoring, financial, or even personal. The key is to communicate the need for help so that you can be directed to the appropriate resource. 

Are you involved on campus? If so, how?

In past years at Oregon Tech I have had campus jobs as a teaching assistant for anatomy and physiology and chemistry, as a library assistant, and as part of the leadership and planning committee for new student orientation (NSO). This year I have also been elected president of the MLS student club: ASCLS: OIT Student Chapter. 

Have you participated in any internships or externships during your time at Oregon Tech? Did you gain valuable experience from them?

At this time I have not been on externship, though I will be wrapping up my time at Oregon Tech with one at the end of 2018. I have partaken in such programs in the past at other schools, and I expect that my MLS externship will be richly rewarding and highly applicable to my future career. The ability to gain real world hands-on job experience with the security of student status is invaluable.

Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation?

There are many ways to specialize in MLS, with many different excellent graduate programs across the country and I do plan to earn a Master's at some time in the future. However, I see the potential for a better understanding of what studies I wish to pursue in the future by having first worked in the field.  

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

Having now attended courses at both the Klamath Falls and Wilsonville campuses, I am in the position to say that both campuses are great, for different reasons. Klamath Falls provides a more traditional campus, larger student body, more classes on campus, and many outdoor activities. While Wilsonville provides the more metro experience by being close to both Salem and Portland, and all the opportunities that come with living in a large city. It can be an adjustment, with different benefits and challenges, to live in either location, but it's still Oregon Tech, with the same high quality education and personal relationships with staff, faculty, and other students.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I love the one on one interaction with my instructors here at Oregon Tech.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I choose Oregon Tech because when it comes to education smaller is better. I love the one on one interaction with my instructors here at Oregon Tech. Plus how can you beat Oregon?

What do you like most about your program?

To me the Mechanical Engineering Technology (MET) degree is the best balance between practical experience and theory. As an MET major I get to choose between Manufacturing Engineering Technology (MFG) elective classes such as CNC Machining (Computer Numerical Control) and Mechanical Engineering (MECH) courses such as Parametric Modeling better known as Solidworks.

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

I am passionate about re-inventing what people think is possible. Specifically, in the metal fabrication industry, by using modern technology and automation to push the limits of what is possible in fabrication today.

What would be your dream job?

My dream job is to own my own precision metal fabrication and machine shop that specializes in achieving the impossible. Specifically, in the custom metal fabrication industry. This could be automotive based, industrial, or both.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

Sean Sloan’s Fluid Mechanics (MECH 318) class was hands down my favorite class so far. It was in this class that I discovered the true value of mathematics by learning how to control water and other fluids, something I previously knew nothing about, through the use of mathematics.

Are you involved on campus? If so, how?

The Catalyze Klamath Falls Competition last year was how I was involved on campus. This year it is though leading my own senior projects team of 7 (myself included) that I stay involved on campus.

Have you participated in any internships or externships during your time at Oregon Tech? Did you gain valuable experience from them? 

Although I have not done any internship while at Oregon Tech, I have started two businesses and the experience has been invaluable. Currently I own and operate MOG Metalworks & Design and have found Klamath Falls to be an exceptional community for startups.

Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation?

I will more than likely take on a part or full-time engineering job while continuing to grow my business MOG Metalworks & Design.

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

Take the time to get to know your instructors! They are all great people that truly want the best for their students! 

Don’t be afraid to take risks. Oregon Tech is a great place to push yourself to become a top performer.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Majoring in Medical Laboratory Science at Oregon Tech was the absolute perfect match for my career goals and aspirations.
StudentProfile.Biography:
When I was in high school, I had the privilege of interning at a plant pathology lab. While there, I thoroughly enjoyed conducting experiments and carrying out laboratory procedures. Even though I have always known that my career aspirations were related to the medical field, Medical Laboratory Science was the perfect blend between the laboratory and my passion to be an outstanding member of the medical field.

Majoring in Medical Laboratory Science at Oregon Tech was the absolute perfect match for my career goals and aspirations. I have nothing but the utmost gratitude for my instructors’ guidance and support throughout my program and I could not have completed this stage of my life without my parents, family, and friends’ unconditional love and encouragement. Above all, I am blessed that the Almighty has provided me with knowledge, strength, and guidance during this journey. ​

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Oregon Tech’s MLS program and inspiring staff are dedicated to their students to achieve their goals with compassion and sincerity, shaping us into becoming the best we can be, heartening our passions and personal drive to learn, do, and see so much more.
StudentProfile.Biography:
At an early age, I’ve always had a genuine love for the sciences behind laboratory science. Since starting my journey four years ago, it has been the most fulfilling years of my life. Oregon Tech’s MLS program and inspiring staff are dedicated to their students to achieve their goals with compassion and sincerity, shaping us into becoming the best we can be, heartening our passions and personal drive to learn, do, and see so much more. The ability to be a part of the medical field where I can contribute to something bigger than me will be wholly fulfilling.

Today I can look back at all my experiences... all its ups, downs and sideways moments… I can see that my path has lead me to exactly where I am today… where I’m meant to be. I will miss my cohort family every day. I can’t wait to start my new adventure!

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Without the support of my family, friends, and MLS (Medical Laboratory Science) instructors none of this would have been possible.
StudentProfile.Biography: Being a college graduate was never something I thought would or could happen to me. I did my life a little backwards. I married young, had a child and life just happened. In my early 30's I finally figured out what wanted to do. With the support of my husband and daughter I enrolled in community college. 5 years later and I've finally reached my goal and on Saturday, December 16th 2017, I became a college graduate. Without the support of my family, friends, and MLS  instructors none of this would have been possible. My time in the MLS program gave me the confidence of knowing that I had made the right decision 5 years ago. The instructors of this program truly want the best for all of us and will do everything they can to help everyone.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: The courses of study in the MLS program is quite satisfactory, the lecture classes give me the basic knowledge about Medical Laboratory, and I can practice the knowledge acquired from lectures in lab days.
StudentProfile.Biography: I wanted to do something more than just synthesizing chemical products in a lab, and actually serve the people and the community. The joint MLS program offered by OIT and OHSU caught my eyes among other search results, and it’s a lab related career.  While I can relate the MLS program with my previous lab experiences, and a career as a MLS would also enable me to serve the people and community. It’s simply a kill two birds with one stone choice for me. The courses of study in the MLS program is quite satisfactory, the lecture classes give me the basic knowledge about Medical Laboratory, and I can practice the knowledge acquired from lectures in lab days. This unique combination helped someone like me with almost no previous biology background tremendously. And now I’m so excited to begin my career as a Medical Laboratory Scientist. ​

StudentProfile.TeaserText: My classmates are always willing to help me with studying or scanning, and my professors care about me and my professional success.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Awards/Accomplishments while at Oregon Tech: President’s List for six terms

Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech because it is the only accredited public university on the West Coast that offers a bachelor's in Vascular Technology. OIT has a national reputation for producing the best Vascular Technologists, and I wanted to be a part of the prestige.

What do you like most about your program?

I like how supportive and tight-knit my program is. My classmates are always willing to help me with studying or scanning, and my professors care about me and my professional success. I feel like an individual on campus, and not just a number, because everyone is interested in getting to know you.

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

I would like to establish a maximum number of scans that are allowed per day in order to protect technologists and their careers. Work related musculoskeletal disorders are common occurrences in this field and leave many technologists in pain or out of jobs. Having a limit will help technologists save their muscles from overuse and injury. 

What would be your dream job?

My dream job would be an ultrasound technologist in a hospital. I would like to cross-train into Echocardiography after I graduate and be able to perform both vascular and heart studies.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

My favorite class was the class involving peripheral arterial disease, because I love learning about arteries. I began scanning in this course, and while it was challenging, it was exceptionally rewarding. I could envision my future in this class because it prepares you to enter the real world and scan actual patients.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

I wish everyone knew how open and supportive professors are at Oregon Tech. The medical imaging professors from all five programs support students in other faculty’s programs. They are always willing to talk and advise, even if the students are not in their program. I feel like I am a part of something and have people cheering me on. 

Are you involved on campus? If so, how?

I am the treasurer of the Vascular Technology Club and a member of Circle K. I also am a Peer Consultant and Supplemental Instructor for ultrasound physics. 

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

If I could go back and do college over, I would form relationships with my professors earlier. Professors at OIT are friendly and love to talk with students, but I was too intimidated to visit their offices. They are valuable tools to use in order to learn more about the program you are interested in and to enhance your understanding of course material.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: What I enjoy most about the vascular technology program so far is how much I’ve been learning from the excellent staff and how supportive all the students are.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech because it was the closest and most affordable school that offered programs I was interested in. I was also attracted to their very high employment rate and how successful and prepared their graduates are. Another interesting thing that drew me to Oregon Tech is that my grandparents met there and I have other family members and friends that attended and spoke very highly of it.

What do you like most about your program?

What I enjoy most about the vascular technology program so far is how much I’ve been learning from the excellent staff and how supportive all the students are. All of the information excites me because it is relevant to my future career, and everything related to the vascular system intrigues me. Cardiovascular disease is very prominent in our society, so that’s why I chose vascular technology to help do my part in helping patients and making a difference in this career field.

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

I’m excited to be a part of the process of helping people with cardiovascular problems get the help they need to be healthier. Another goal I wish to achieve in this particular field is to advocate for better cardiovascular health among our society. I would hope to inform and help avoid future cardiovascular disease since it’s such a massive problem in our society that can be better prevented with healthier eating and exercise choices. 

What would be your dream job?

My dream job would be a vascular technologist at a hospital where I will be able to learn a lot, expand my job abilities, and potentially cross train for other similar jobs. I’m excited to work somewhere fast paced like a hospital, but it gives me comfort that there are different options, such as clinics, in case I ever have a family or have a need for more regular hours. It would also be somewhere warm and sunny, so I can spend as much free time outside as possible. 

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

So far one of my favorite classes has been cardiovascular physiology. It has been my most challenging class, but I really enjoyed the content of the course and I learned so much valuable information. This class showed me how much the staff wants us to learn so that we will be prepared in our future careers. 

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

I wish everyone knew how career and future focused the whole school is and how highly regarded all of their graduates are. If someone is able to find a subject at Oregon Tech that they are passionate about, there’s no doubt in my mind that they have the ability to reach their goals and set themselves up for a great future doing what they love. All of the students attending are very focused and the staff has the resources and knowledge to help everyone succeed.

Are you involved on campus? If so, how?

Yes, I’m an anatomy teacher’s assistant and also a tutor for anatomy and physiology. It’s very rewarding to try to help students be successful since I was in the same place only a year before. I also enjoy informing students about the vascular technology program because many students are unaware of all the benefits this career field has to offer. 

Have you participated in any internships or externships during your time at Oregon Tech? Did you gain valuable experience from them?

A major part of our program is having a year of externship for our final year before we graduate. Although I haven’t experienced it yet, I know that this externship is where I will gain the most skill and be able to apply what I’ve learned in a real life setting. Having a whole year to gain experience in a hospital setting and working with real patients is what prepares Oregon Tech students and makes them stand out to future employers.

Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation?

At the moment all I know is that I want to start working right after I graduate. I’m hoping that my externship is somewhere that I really enjoy, so that I can potentially get offered a job at that hospital. It would be nice to work somewhere close to home in Oregon, but I also have a desire to experience new places and see what other states have to offer. 

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

I believe one of the best ways to have a great experience at Oregon Tech is to find ways to be involved on campus, because it’s a great way to meet people with similar interests and also a way to keep busy and learn more about different majors. Even if someone isn’t certain on what career path they want to take, Oregon Tech provides so many excellent options and have many different ways to learn more about each major to help everyone find their best fit.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Oregon Tech prepares you for an actual career that you can start the day after you graduate.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I knew I wanted to work in the medical field to help patients. I found that I am very good with technology and problem solving, and those things put together I found that an imaging program would be the best career for me that I would most enjoy. Also, I wanted to stay in Oregon!

What do you like most about your program?

I love learning about human anatomy and physiology. It is such a relevant topic and I find it very fascinating to learn about things that are happening within yourself.

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

I would like to practice medical technology with the patients' best interest in mind. I think healthcare has moved in a way where the world has started to treat patients like object that need fixing. I believe this field lacks empathy and I would like to be one person in this field that does not.

What would be your dream job?

I would love to work with a variety of people and perform many different types of scans. I would love to travel to different countries and work with communities where vascular technology is not typically accessible in order to help educate a community about potential health risks.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

I really enjoyed Cardiovascular physiology. Again this subject pertains to us all and it is very fascinating to see how our own bodies work!

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

I wish people knew that this isn't the type of school to just complete your bachelor’s degree and go away. Oregon Tech prepares you for an actual career that you can start the day after you graduate. I’m a little bitter about this subject since I received my bachelor’s degree from another university in Human Physiology, but had no clue what to do after. That degree did not prepare me for the real world, but Oregon Tech does prepare you. 

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

I’d like to tell students to really take the time to know what each career would be like before choosing a major. Go shadow all the jobs you think you would like to ensure it is something you would actually enjoy. I did this after I got my first bachelors and wish I had done it a lot sooner.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: We have cameras and processing stations that give us real life applications to our field.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

My mom graduated from OIT and I knew I wanted to study Nuclear Medicine so I looked into the program here. It was the best school and program I had ever seen. Oregon Tech is very student-oriented and will always want the best for my education. I couldn't have picked a better school.

What do you like most about your program?

I love how hands-on our programs is. We have cameras and processing stations that give us real life applications to our field. The professors invest in your education and give you every tool you need to succeed and then some. We have the privilege of cross training into MRI, CT, Mammography, etc. so our program director implemented classes to help us achieve those certifications. This program is truly one of the best.  

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

If I could change anything it would be the perceptions and market of Nuclear Medicine. It seems that most people either have no idea what Nuclear Medicine is or the name itself scares people off. 

What would be your dream job?

My dream job is to be a Nuclear Medicine Technologist who brightens patients’ days. If I can take a terrifying and unknown situation and turn it into just a moment of bliss I will. I want to be that person who brings even an hour of joy to all of my patients in a time of fear. 

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

I have loved all of my Nuclear Medicine classes. Learning how we image the way the body functions is truly indescribable.  

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

I would just want everyone to know that when you go to Oregon Tech you have an endless amount of support and encouragement no matter what degree you choose.   

Are you involved on campus? If so, how?

Yes, I am the ASOIT representative for the Nuclear Medicine club.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I chose Oregon Tech for two reasons; small class sizes and hands-on education.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I chose Oregon Tech for two reasons; small class sizes and hands-on education. Coming from a small high school, I knew I needed to be in a classroom environment like Oregon Tech. Class sizes range from 10 to 30 students in my major. Having small classes allows you to develop relationships with your peers and be able to have one-on-one communication with your professors.

What do you like most about your program?

Oregon Tech as a whole strives to provide their students with a “hands-on, real-world education.” This is very prominent within my degree. By providing this type of education, I have been able to apply the skills I learn in the classroom out into the real world. We are constantly working with local businesses, exercising our skills and creating relationships with business owners, which allows us to develop a competitive edge over graduates from other universities. I like that all of our professors are industry trained, it helps them deliver a customized teaching experience to students outside of textbook concepts. 

What would be your dream job?

My dream job would consist of working with small business to design and create creative websites and logos for their business.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

It’s honestly hard to pick a favorite class! All of our professors do such a great job keeping our classes relevant and up to date. I really enjoy the classes where we have to go out and work with local businesses. It helps us develop a wide range of skills that are necessary for our degree, while at the same time, allowing us to see the impact that we have in our community.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: OIT has very nice teachers, who will go out of their way to help you if you are struggling with the material.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Awards/Accomplishments while at Oregon Tech: Awarded FIRST Robotics Scholarship, President's List

Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I was looking for a college that gave me the options to go more in-depth into the field of computers, down to the components that make up our modern world. And OIT was the only school with the reputation and specific major that would best suit me. 

What do you like most about your program?

It allows me to get a few internships within my field of study during my time at college. 

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

I am fascinated by the progress of microprocessors and electrical devices. And want to further this progress by changing the way we approach battery technologies.  

What would be your dream job?

My dream job would be at a work place where problems are constantly thrown at me and I am required to solve them. Not only that but managing and updating older systems that have already been put in place.  

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

My favorite classes so far have been digital logic 1 and speech. I like digital logic 1 because its teaching me the fundamentals that I will need to understand how the components of a computer communicate and share information. While speech has taught me important skills that I must keep reinforcing in work group environments.  

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

OIT has very nice teachers, who will go out of their way to help you if you are struggling with the material. 

Are you involved on campus? If so, how?

I am part of Latino club where we have meetings every week and talk about life on campus as well as events that we will be participating in, to spread awareness of our culture. 

Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation?

I am looking to get a job in the semiconductor industry in either California or Oregon. 

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

Oregon Tech is a great campus if you are interested in any technological field as well as medical fields. There are a lot of opportunities to excel and get involved in campus.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I fell in love with the CSET department and became part of the family - I never considered going anywhere else after that.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Awards/Accomplishments while at Oregon Tech: Outstanding Community Service Nominee

Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I left my first college after one semester and moved back home. My mom encouraged me to keep taking classes while I figured out what my next step would be. I chose the Software program because I thought computers were “cool.” I fell in love with the CSET department and became part of the family - I never considered going anywhere else after that. 

What do you like most about your program?

By far the greatest thing about the Software program and CSET department is the family atmosphere. The professors have an open-door policy so we can talk to them basically any time they’re not in class, they even host pizza study sessions and code parties. Our professors are so much more than just teachers – they’re life coaches, mentors, and second parents. 

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

There are so many stigmas related to the computer science/engineering industry and I’d love to see those dissipate. Like any stereotype, a very low number of the people in CSET and in the career field actually fall into the basement-dwelling, anti-social, nerd category. I think it can make people undervalue and discredit people in the technology industry and would be great if we were able to help turn the tide.  

What would be your dream job?

My dream job is to be a user interface specialist or consultant. I love the design aspect of programming and I think that a lot of good programmers struggle with creativity. That's definitely my forte and I hope I can apply it in industry someday.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

Honestly, my favorite classes have been those related to my Human Interaction minor. I've learned so much about communication and in my program, those aren't skills we capitalize on. I firmly believe that you can be the best programmer in the world, but if you can't be a good team member and have good communication with those around you, no one will want to work with you. I strive to apply those interaction concepts every day in school and at work.

Are you involved on campus? If so, how?

I'm a CSET Ambassador which means I help with CSET outreach events whether it's Code For A Day or going to community colleges in Southern Oregon to speak with students about transferring to OIT. I'm also the CSET Media Coordinator and help make graphics for the Purvine TV and flyers for events. I also work as a CSET TA and grader, for Athletics as tech support, and for the recruiting office. I previously worked in the Registrar's office and for Campus Safety. I'm also a member of the Society of Women Engineers.  

Have you participated in any internships or externships during your time at Oregon Tech? Did you gain valuable experience from them?

I'm in the MECOP program and have gone on one internship. I worked at Portland General Electric as an IT Applications intern. It was an amazing experience and I'm so glad that I got the chance to work with such incredible people. For the first three months, I was on an all-intern team and we developed a web application for PGE employees. During the second half on my internship, I worked with the Business Intelligence teams.

Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation?

After I graduate, I'll go on my second MECOP internship and within a few years, I hope to explore the possibility of a graduate school in either a communication or management field.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Every instructor I have had at OIT has been awesome and I think that made a huge difference in whether I would continue with the program or not.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I was a student at PCC working towards an AAS degree. I had no clue what I was going to do after getting that degree because it did not transfer well to other colleges and I was wondering where I could go. I overheard an instructor of mine speaking to another student during a class break, and he mentioned that he continued his studies at OIT. I was still new to Oregon at the time and had no clue where OIT was so I looked it up, set an appointment with an advisor, and decided to become an owl.  

What do you like most about your program?

The instructors. I hated school when I was younger because I hated my teachers... and I was slightly rebellious. However, every instructor I have had at OIT has been awesome and I think that made a huge difference in whether I would continue with the program or not.

What would be your dream job?

Rock star. I tried that. It didn't work so here I am in school.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

I think my favorite class so far has been Small Group Communications. I didn't think I was going to like that class because I don't generally like working with others all that often. However, we ended up building a guitar that lit up whenever it was played and that ended up being one of my favorite classes.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

It's an awesome school with awesome instructors. 

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

Make sure your degree transfers over. Wasting time at a community college sucks.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: This school has an incredible reputation for its medical imaging degrees, which are the perfect combination of rigorous and rewarding.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Awards/Accomplishments while at Oregon Tech:

  • Cumulative 4.0 GPA and President’s List each term.

  • Human Interaction minor.
