Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

I wish everyone knew about the OIT smartphone app before transferring. The app contains different sections that include a student feed, buying & selling, lost & found, and a housing section. At the time of my program acceptance I wasn’t aware of the app. I had difficulty looking for a place to live in Klamath Falls and wished that I could somehow connect with other students that were attending OIT. If I had known about this app, my transition process would have gone smoother.

Are you involved on campus? If so, how? 

Yes, I am in the echocardiography club. We fundraise money for our program by volunteering work hours to the school and community.  

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

OIT is a smaller university that is located in rural Klamath Falls. This aspect may not be so appealing, especially if you’re coming from a larger city. Before moving here, I had similar thoughts but ended up falling in love with the college and community. I also realized there are many benefits to its size and location. For example, OIT’s atmosphere is extremely welcoming, and unlike larger colleges, students and faculty have more autonomy and have closer relationships providing better education. Klamath Falls is also the sunniest city in Oregon and is geographically diverse providing great opportunity for outdoor adventuring.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I am very passionate about changing hydroelectric dams because dams can drastically change the ecology of the effected river.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

I picked Oregon Tech because it was a small school and it had a Renewable Energy Engineering degree. There were also a lot of examples of Renewable Energy on Campus.

What do you like most about your program?  

I really enjoy the small class sizes. It allows you to really get to know your professors. I also love the hands on approach in the labs which really helps you get an understanding of the subject.

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

I am very passionate about changing hydroelectric dams because dams can drastically change the ecology of the effected river. It also hinders the migration of fish. I am also very interested in algae based bio-fuels because I think it could be one of the fuel sources of the future.

What would be your dream job?

I would absolutely love to work in an algae based bio-fuels company.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

I really enjoyed electrochemistry because there was hands on activities in the labs and my professor was really passionate about the topics. We also got to do some awesome activities like dissecting a battery and creating our own solar panels from scratch.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

Your professors are really receptive to any ideas you have. I am currently working on my own semi-independent project with one of my math professors I had during my first term. Also, don’t dismiss the Rock. My Rock adviser is one of my best friends on campus and it is really nice just to have a nice place to go and talk to others. I think the Rock has helped me the most in my college experience

Are you involved on campus? If so, how?

I am involved with the Circle K club. It is a club dedicated to community service and it is great for making new friends. I highly recommend it.

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

Be sure that you really want to go into the field you choose because college isn’t cheap. Also, be sure to have to some fun while you are at college. You can even have some fun by adding some humor into speeches or papers. This makes them a little bit more enjoyable.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I believe that the desire to constantly improve myself and never settling for where I am now fuels my success.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose this program (major)?

My previous roommate had recommended that I switch majors to do accounting with him, causing me to switch from pre-physical therapy. His family members were involved in the accounting world and said it was a good career field to go into.

What are you passionate about changing in this particular field and why? How are you planning to use your degree in the future?

I would like to change the misunderstanding that the only job opportunities with an accounting degree is to work a few months out of the year doing taxes. Although tax is a major portion of accounting, the degree can open doors into various business fields.

Currently I am using my degree to intern at JELD-WEN as a Junior Accountant, but I have accepted another job offer to work for ACA Compliance Group as a Performance Analyst.

Why did you decide to join TOP?

I had previously joined the TRIO program at Centralia College in Centralia, Washington and they were helpful in navigating the college process. When I transferred to Oregon Tech I wanted to receive the same assistance in getting through my bachelor’s degree.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

Oregon Tech is great for students since all the instructors and faculty are helpful. Professors here want you to succeed and have the skills necessary to find a great career. I have been able to drop into my professor’s office whenever I needed help and they are always willing to answer any question.

What is your favorite hobby, and do you have any experiences you would like to share regarding that hobby?

My favorite hobby for most of my life has been baseball and is the main reason that I ended up at Oregon Tech. I had the opportunity to play for a single season and was blessed do so. I also enjoy trap shooting and team roping when I am back in my home town of Las Vegas, NV. Other interests that I have include weight training and jiu-jitsu when I have the time.

What fuels you to succeed?

I believe that the desire to constantly improve myself and never settling for where I am now fuels my success. Taking this same mindset, I am constantly competing with myself whether it is in school, work, or whatever hobby that I am trying to get into.

Who is your favorite professor and why? Do you know any interesting facts about that particular professor?

I have several professors that I am quite fond of and that have been nothing but helpful. Two professors that I have interacted with the most and have put up with me for three years are Carmen Morgan and Richard Bailey. I know Carmen has more certifications than I have letters in my name. I know Richard farms in his down time.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I was drawn to the REE program for its inclusion of a variety of engineering disciplines as well as the career field that it prepared me for.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose this program (major)?

I was drawn to the REE program for its inclusion of a variety of engineering disciplines as well as the career field that it prepared me for.

What are you passionate about changing in this particular field and why? How are you planning to use your degree in the future?

I am open to a wide range of career paths but working in the power industry, upgrading our grid system, or in a number of renewable energy industries would be great. I think increasing the amount of energy generation by renewables is a direction we need to go.

Why did you decide to join TOP?

College was a challenge much larger than any I had faced before, and I needed all the support that I could get. TOP has been large force in my success at Oregon Tech.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

Oregon Tech is a tight-knit community where it can seem that you have connections with nearly every person on campus. This makes meeting new friends and finding resources very easy.

What is your favorite hobby, and do you have any experiences you would like to share regarding that hobby?

My favorite hobby while at Oregon Tech has been participating on the Oregon Tech Rugby Team. I remember taking a big step out of my comfort zone by going to the first practice but have never regretted it. I recommend reaching out to at least one group or club on campus your first week.

What fuels you to succeed?

I have goals providing for a family and succeeding now will make that a lot easier.

Who is your favorite professor and why? Do you know any interesting facts about that particular professor?

Professor Sedlock was an inspiration. Even though he was past retirement he remained very enthusiastic about the subjects he taught.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I am the first person in my family ever to earn a bachelor's degree. I wanted to model for my children the value and benefits of higher education.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose this program (major)?

It was local, had low student to faculty ratio, was an APA accredited psychology programs, applied experience, and has a 96% post-employment rate after graduation.

What are you passionate about changing in this particular field and why?

I would like to advance the understanding of stereotypes and prejudices that are still prevalent for those who experience mental and physical disabilities, foster inclusive education for students who have unique challenges, and promote person centered counseling and case managing that is genuinely strength based.

How are you planning to use your degree in the future?

To advocate for vulnerable at-risk members of our community through a job in human services and or education. To speak publicly on the need to improve our services.

Why did you decide to join TOP?

I knew I needed their professional and personal services to help increase my successful completion of both my academic and social goals. They helped me stay focused on my goals and made sure I took care of myself and my family.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

When you are a student it can be easy to forget the incredible beauty that surrounds us on campus. I would encourage students to put their phones away and take the time between classes to chat with other people and look around, maybe hike the O or just remember to just breathe. Social connections and nature breaks can reduce anxiety an improve your quality of life.

What is your favorite hobby, and do you have any experiences you would like to share regarding that hobby?

I love heading to the woods, lake, or the coast. The long drive helps me clear my head, and nature rejuvenates my spirit. I am always amazed how much better I perform when I take a break from studies.

What fuels you to succeed?

The desire to advocate and educate more effectively that can create a change in community mindset. I am the first person in my family ever to earn a bachelor's degree. I wanted to model for my children the value and benefits of higher education.

Who is your favorite professor and why? Do you know any interesting facts about that particular professor?

Dr. Petersen is one of my favorite professors. I really respect his integrity demonstrated in and out of the classroom, knowledge in our field, application of positive psychology, and accessibility to his students. He is a humble and patient man.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Externship is just a long interview so do your best to show your site that you are a good worker and you will have a lot of doors open up for you
StudentProfile.Biography:
Current Job Title & Place of Employment: Registered vascular technologist at St. Luke’s Medical Center, Boise, ID

1. What did you like most about your time at Oregon Tech? Making friends with classmates and being able to continue those relationships into our careers. It’s great having people that can relate to what you’re going through on extern and when you first start your career. It’s also nice to hear about job openings before they open to the general public.

2. What do you like most about your profession? I like being able to see patients throughout their whole vascular process. Whether that is finding deep vein thrombosis and seeing the patient for check-ups until it is gone or seeing a patient with and acute arterial process in the ER and then following up with them after surgery. You get to meet a lot of people and you form a relationship with a lot of them because you see them multiple times a year.

3. How long after graduation did it take you to find a job? I had a job guaranteed before I graduated at my extern site. I was also able to get one of my good friends and classmate a job which is really cool to be able to have a classmate as your coworker.

5. How do you feel your time at Oregon Tech prepared you for your current job/continuing studies? Oregon Tech really prepared me for my current job. I think that having a 1-year externship was crucial in being a good technologist. Seeing disease in books is a lot different than seeing it in real life.

6. Is there anything you wish you would have done during your time at Oregon Tech that you didn’t? I wish that I would have taken my family to Crater Lake at least one more time while at Oregon Tech. 

7. Do you maintain professional relationships with any of your professors? Yes, I actually just asked Prof. Leah Jolly for some information on arterial stents the other day.

8. What advice would you give to a current student at Oregon Tech? Study hard and be prepared to work hard on your externship. Externship is just a long interview so do your best to show your site that you are a good worker and you will have a lot of doors open up for you. Even if you don’t get a job at your externship site, the vascular world is small and the people at your externship can refer you to friends at other sites.

What is the best class you have taken at Oregon Tech?

Organic Chemistry, it was interesting and interactive.

StudentProfile.Biography:

What is the best class you have taken at Oregon Tech?

Manufacturing Tool Design because we turn our crazy ideas into actual stuff.

Campus Involvement:

The staff.

What is the best class you have taken at Oregon Tech?

Good question, I love all my classes.

Campus Involvement:

Tech Night Volunteer

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Applied Psychology
StudentProfile.Biography:
What is your favorite thing about Oregon Tech?

The small class room sizes.

What is the best class you have taken at Oregon Tech?

Behavioral Modification! Why? Because now I know how to change someone’s behavior.

Campus Involvement:

PSYCH-ED President, Communications Officer and student Ambassador

Fun Fact:

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Electrical Engineering Senior. Graduate Student, MS in Engineering
StudentProfile.Biography:
What is your favorite thing about Oregon Tech?

Emphasis in hands-on learning. Classes are taught by PhD level instructors instead of TA’s. Small instructor-to-students ratio. Non-traditional student campus. Emphasis in polytechnic education. Cultural diversity & plurality are considered assets.

What is the best class you have taken at Oregon Tech?

Most of the classes I’ve taken at Oregon Tech were very interesting. It’s hard to tell.

Campus Involvement:

Assistant MESA Coordinator

Fun Fact:

I am Chilean. How many Chileans do you know? I was born in the Atacama Desert: the driest place on Earth. I have a masters in Clinical Psychology and have about 10 years of counseling/therapy experience in both Chile and the U.S.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I plan on using the skills I have learned in school and in my own life for working with children.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose this program (major)?

I chose my major because I always liked psychology and anything that had to do with learning about the brain and the mind. Also, I wanted to work with children, and I knew that having a background in psychology would be helpful in the future.

What are you passionate about changing in this particular field and why? How are you planning to use your degree in the future?

I plan on using the skills I have learned in school and in my own life for working with children. I would like to help them think about what they want to do in life, and then help them start on the path to get there. Most importantly, however, I would like to make sure they understand the work piece that will be needed to get there.

Why did you decide to join TOP?

I joined TOP because I was told that it could help me while attending Oregon Tech. After meeting everyone who works with TOP, I thought this would be an excellent place for me to get involved.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

If I had to pick something, I would say it would be the amount of time a person would need to study. One thing about Oregon Tech is that getting to the end of the road will not be the easiest thing for everyone, so it is best to study.

What is your favorite hobby, and do you have any experiences you would like to share regarding that hobby?

One of my hobbies is track and field. I have been running for about 9 years now, but there is still so much I do not know. For now, I am just going to keep learning, running and coaching.

What fuels you to succeed?

I would say that I am a person who does not give up. Knowing that I have a young daughter who one day will look at what I have done in my own life, I would like her to see someone who is determined and never gives up. I hope that can help her in her own life one day.

Who is your favorite professor and why? Do you know any interesting facts about that particular professor?

My favorite professor is Dr. John Borgen. He was the first person I learned behavior modification from, and that has been one of the most important things I have learned while in school.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I had a few friends join TOP and they loved the supportive one-on-one attention they were given.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose this program (major)?

The answer just happened upon me one day. I was a student at City College of San Francisco, nearing the end of my general course work, and still unsure of what major I should pick or even where I was going to transfer. I came from a construction background, so the natural choice would have been Civil or Mechanical Engineering but neither of them spoke to me. After countless dead-end searches, I became frustrated by all the questions piling up on one another. So I headed off for a break at my favorite coffee spot, grabbed a paper, and thought a good read would help ease my mind.

While browsing through the paper I happened upon an article that talked about this technology called ‘Carbon Capture.’ At first glance, it didn’t seem like much but the more I read the more enthralled I became. It was so fascinating that we could take such an active stance against global warming with this technology! As I continued to read, the article concluded with something around the lines of ‘…and if this technology sounds interesting you should check out Oregon Institute of Technology’s Renewable Energy Engineering Program...’ I was sold and applied soon after.

What are you passionate about changing in this particular field and why? How are you planning to use your degree in the future?

The technology that brought me to Oregon Tech is what I’m most passionate about. Renewable Energy is all about using a resource that can be replenished without harming the environment. Taking a hazardous waste product and upcycling it into a useable eco-friendly material also has its place within Renewable Energy. I want to help bridge the technological gap between today’s technology and the innovations of the future. The devices of today will be around for some time after they have been outmoded, but the actions of today will also ripple long after we’re gone. Carbon Dioxide will be one of those long-lasting consequences of our action. That is why I am using the knowledge that I’ve gathered over the years to design and implement my own system that actively captures carbon dioxide out of the air.

Why did you decide to join TOP?

I had a few friends join TOP and they loved the supportive one-on-one attention they were given. They’d tell me about the Coffee Connect hosted by TOP every Tuesday afternoon and one of the many guest speakers that have come to inspire students. There was even one time that they were able to go to Boeing for a tour! The thing is, even with all these amazing activities, what was spoke most highly of was the staff. They create such a welcoming environment and their doors are always open. This is why I chose TOP. It’s a great place to connect with people and the mentorship offered is truly invaluable. It’s a program that cares about you, not only as a student but as a person.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

The tools to success are offered but you must seek them out. There’s a bit of a learning curve to find all the resources specific to your goals. Once you find your road to success, it’s comforting to know how much support there really is for you. Therefore, I would suggest showing up to events held by the school because those human connections will take you farther than you think.

What is your favorite hobby, and do you have any experiences you would like to share regarding that hobby?

Small business development. It is extremely hard but learning about how to start my own business and helping others to do so is very satisfying. Right now I’m still in the infancy stages of my own business, but going out to generate interest, making the cold calls, and hearing people express genuine interest is truly rewarding. I still plan on keeping my day job and finishing up school though. So, in the the meantime starting my business is pretty much my hobby.

What fuels you to succeed?

Passion. It’s one of those things that’s frustrating because you can never get a straight answer of how to find it, but when you do you’re hooked. I count myself very fortunate to have found mine. It’s a passion that leads to success. We all fail, trust me I have, but if you have a passion you won’t care as much about the failure. You’ll care so much more about the success. It’s unfortunate that we’re conditioned to think of failure as a negative concept because without it we can’t adapt our way of thinking. When we’re able to change our mindset, the smallest victories fuel our drive to push forward. That fuel moves us past the negative side of failure and onward to using it as a constructive tool, leading to even more successes. Passion forces you to come to this realization, and it is passion that will set you apart in a crowded room.

Who is your favorite professor and why? Do you know any interesting facts about that particular professor?

Michal Kawka. Although he is not a professor, the lessons he teaches students are eye-opening and inspiring. He’s able to share a perspective that is understanding but challenges you to expand your way of thinking. Edging you away from the quick answers with short-term solutions into carefully laid out plans that optimize the return on your time. As students, we can become so entrenched with just trying to make it through one class or one quarter. These short-term hurdles can often distract us from what really matters, life after the finish line. What happens after we make it out of college? Life doesn’t always hand us a syllabus to outline what’s to be expected, same as some professors you may have had. For some people the next step comes naturally…but for others, they can become bewildered by this whole new process.

Regardless of where you might stand, Michal Kawka offers a massive wealth of knowledge that will push you to reach your full potential. A side note, Michal is from Poland and speaks very fondly of home. The stories he shares are genuine and offer a glimpse into how people outside of the U.S. think. I remember how excited Michal was when he was first introduced to Marzena Terry, another Polish native. It was a treat to listen in on their conversation and I would suggest anyone stop by to talk to these two wonderful people.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I picked mechanical engineering because I like understanding how things work, and I wanted a chance to create new products that make a positive difference in the world around me.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Why did you choose this program (major)?

I grew up playing with LEGOs, K’NEX and a lot of freedom in my dad’s woodshop. I was always coming up with new things and had a book of invention ideas. Throughout my years of school, I was given the opportunity to explore my creativity through the Gifted and Talented Program and then an intro to engineering class in high school. After I realized that I could use my math and science skills combined with my creativity as a career, I was hooked. I picked mechanical engineering because I like understanding how things work, and I wanted a chance to create new products that make a positive difference in the world around me.

What are you passionate about changing in this particular field and why? How are you planning to use your degree in the future?

I plan to use my degree to pursue a career where I can work on new technologies or improve the ones we already have. I am passionate about all facets of sustainability. I believe that we can all live in such a way that does not damage our environment nearly as much as we do now, and I want to be part of the solution in changing these technologies and habits.

Why did you decide to join TOP?

I decided to join TOP because I was in my high school TRiO program, and it was an incredible network for me. They helped me apply to 25 colleges, took care of the application fees, and provided me with an engineering internship during my senior year of high school. TRiO focused on making sure I knew my options and did everything they could to support me in reaching my collegiate goals. I could not pass up the opportunity to continue TRiO through college and have an amazing support system like this. TOP ended up being a valuable asset for completing my degree, so I am so happy I made that choice.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

Often, we get stuck only hanging out with students in our own major. Oregon Tech has so many bright, friendly people - you just need to get outside of your comfort zone to meet them. I want others to know how welcoming Oregon Tech faculty and students are and that they should take the initiative to look outward for mentors or new groups to join.

What is your favorite hobby, and do you have any experiences you would like to share regarding that hobby?

This year I got into boxing, and I absolutely love it. I like that I’m staying active, providing myself with an outlet for stress, and having fun with people I never would have met otherwise in the Klamath Falls community. The group I box with is very welcoming, and I would suggest joining groups outside of campus for a variety of reasons.

What fuels you to succeed?

As a first-generation college graduate, it is very important to me to have financial freedom in my near future. I also want to have a fulfilling career and life, so I keep that in mind while making important decisions like degree choice or which city I choose to live in.

Who is your favorite professor and why? Do you know any interesting facts about that particular professor?

Sean Sloan in the MMET department has been my favorite professor since my first year. He is so passionate and energetic about engineering, and he passes that feeling on to his students. He is always willing to help with a specific problem or question, and he truly cares about all the students he encounters. Professor Sloan is obsessed with lasers, and he helped to write a book about the theory on how aliens built the great pyramids!

StudentProfile.TeaserText: It’s amazing that I can help engineering students in a surprisingly large array of applications, and regularly see them receive help on projects and various computations from our math professors
StudentProfile.Biography:
Awards/Accomplishments while at Oregon Tech: two terms on the president’s list; awarded membership with the National Society of Collegiate Scholars

1. Why did you choose Oregon Tech?
I liked the small class sizes, high success rate among alumni, amazing engineering programs, and an Applied Mathematics degree program that emphasizes engineering applications. The Renewable Energy Engineering, Electrical Engineering, and Mechanical Engineering programs here all piqued my interest, so it sounded like a fun place to pursue my ambitions in Applied Mathematics, with potential to aid in engineering and design. 

2. What do you like most about your program?
The emphasis on “applied” mathematics gives it a strong real-world connection to engineering and other fields with a powerful and fun conduit for collaboration. It’s amazing that I can help engineering students in a surprisingly large array of applications, and regularly see them receive help on projects and various computations from our math professors. Oregon Tech’s engineers (students and staff alike) are in turn willing and able to help math majors by conveying a different approach to understanding concepts. 

3. What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why? 
While I enjoy applying mathematics to engineering and other fields, I also hope to inter-connect the way math is used in other fields to expand their range of application. For example, there is a convenient method used in circuits (electrical engineering) that can be used to model/calculate traffic in a network of city streets and intersections (civil engineering). With this approach, I hope to create more versatile computational methods, and make it possible for more people to connect with and learn math in a more intuitive way.

4. What would be your dream job?
It may not sound like an illustrious career, but I would love to be a high school and/or college teacher in math and physics. Connecting the way math is used in various applications will help relate it to more students and their interests, that way they’re less likely to dread mathematics or find it useless. During breaks and summer vacation, I’ll also be able to pursue research in engineering and aerodynamics (fringe benefit of being a teacher!).

5. What have been some of your favorite classes and why?
I have enjoyed classes in physics, the calculus series, and Applied Differential Equations because even the most abstract concepts have tons practical uses in the physical world. Also among my favorites are mechanical engineering classes, particularly Engineering Mechanics (Statics & Dynamics), and Fluid Mechanics. There are lots of useful methods and perspectives for problem solving techniques used by engineers and physicists, along with a few handy tweaks in notation. 

6. Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?
There is a surprising large number of programs to help students here at Oregon Tech. These include the Tech Opportunities Program (helps low-income, disabled, and first-generation students), Career Services (to help get that dream job you’re going to school for), and Student Success Center (tutoring and academic help). Everybody should know that Peer Consulting is comprised of fellow students who can relate and are eager to help, backed by dedicated Oregon Tech staff. It truly is a community in its own right. 

7. Are you involved on campus? If so, how? 
Yes, I help fellow students with their studies as a member of Peer Consulting Services in the Student Success Center here on campus. I have not seen a program like this at other colleges I have attended, so I really wanted to be a part of it. If you’re having a tough time with a concept, odds are a fellow student did as well and can likely provide guidance. The best students are the ones who seek help, so no need to fear that doing so means you lack intelligence in any way – that’s the culture here at Oregon Tech! 

8. Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation?
I will most likely pursue a Master of Education degree so I can teach in public education, but not sure what school I’ll attend yet. Meanwhile, I may also teach night classes at a community college, work part time or as a consultant for an engineering company, or participate in research and development to offset expense. 

9. Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?
This level of education requires your A-game – it turns out success is determined by your level of dedication to your chosen field of study, far more than just talent or how famous the school’s name is. An endeavor like this may sound daunting, but if you’re ready to go all-in, you’re also in for a lot of fun and rewarding experiences along the way. With a bit of discipline and an adventurous spirit, career success is just as good after attending Oregon Tech as the big super-elite universities.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: My dream job is one where I get to be a part of the design process in projects that break boundaries in sustainability and performance; I believe the two can go hand in hand.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Awards/Accomplishments while at Oregon Tech:

•             Google Cloud Academic All-American (2018-19)

•             2 x All-American in Cross-Country (2016, 2018)

•             National Women's Cross-Country Champions (team award: 2018)

•             3 x All-American in Track (2019)

•             Represented US in World University Games (2019)

 

1.  Why did you choose Oregon Tech?

Having grown up outside of the States I was unfamiliar with many US universities, so it was Laura Schwartz (our recruiting coordinator for Cross-Country and Track) who introduced me to Oregon Tech. What sold me was the combined opportunity to compete with a team willing to develop me as an athlete and the opportunity to study engineering at a school with a strong hands-on program.

 

2.  What do you like most about your program?

I like that engineering is the real-life application of science. It takes what we learn from our urge to ask why things behave the way they do and creates a how to solve a problem.

 

3.  What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why?

Traditionally engineering can be a little too focused on solving the immediate "problem." We do very well in making things run faster, be stronger, and go further but we don't always consider the end-of-life of a part or how we source the material we use and so on. I would like to be a part of changing that mindset so we can continue to do all these things but in a sustainable way.

 

4.  What would be your dream job?

My dream job is one where I get to be a part of the design process in projects that break boundaries in sustainability and performance; I believe the two can go hand in hand.

 

5.  What have been some of your favorite classes and why?

I've enjoyed the subject matter in almost all my engineering classes, but my favorites have always been those taught by professors who truly enjoy teaching and encourage questions. Sean Sloan, Irina Demeshko, and Joe Stuart are some of the professors that can make even a difficult class a fun one.

 

6.  Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about?

First of all that we're here! Hello? This thing on?! Also that we have quality programs and people here. Often after someone from Oregon Tech gets recognition outside the community, I hear the same whisper amongst the crowd: "who's Oregon Tech?"

 

7.  Are you involved on campus? If so, how?

I am primarily involved on campus as a student-athlete and as a captain on the teams I have represented. As such, I am also a member of the Student-Athlete Advisory Committee.

 

8.  Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation?

My goal is to follow up this degree with a master's degree that looks at sustainable engineering. However, I am also looking for a job in order to help achieve that.

 

9. Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else?

Something I think everyone should know is that being an underdog can be the best gig; it gives you the element of surprise! Being a part of a team and a community that is 'unknown' provides you with the opportunity to be one of the people that makes it known.

StudentProfile.TeaserText: Oregon Tech has provided me with the tools to make a clinic more efficient while implementing best practices.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Awards/Accomplishments while at Oregon Tech: 6 school records at Oregon Tech for track and field, All-American, 9-time national qualifier, Female Breakout Athlete of the Year 2017.

Why did you choose Oregon Tech? I chose Oregon Tech for the opportunity to have a hands-on education and to stand out to employers after graduation. There are incredible opportunities at Oregon Tech to grow outside of the classroom as well; internships, community involvement, and incredible outdoor activities. I toured many colleges, but Oregon Tech stood out to me as soon as I stepped foot on campus.

What do you like most about your program? I love the small class sizes; it feels like you’re getting a personalized education. The healthcare management program has given me opportunities to work at local clinics for class projects, building a network through the community.

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why? The healthcare system in America is a broken place. Long wait times, overcrowded emergency rooms, I want to make sure that these issues can be solved and we are providing patients with quality care. Oregon Tech has provided me with the tools to make a clinic more efficient while implementing best practices.

What would be your dream job? My dream job would be a clinical director. I would love to provide guidance to employees on quality health initiatives, use strategic planning for growing the clinic, and provide an environment where the administrative staff is approachable and employees feel comfortable speaking up.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why? The leadership classes at Oregon Tech have been my favorite. I have always been comfortable in a leadership position, but the tools I’ve gained through these classes have helped turn that passion into a reality. Not only have these classes taught me how to be an effective leader, but how to make a team one cohesive unit, so we can all succeed.

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about? I wish everyone knew how much there is to do in Klamath Falls! Too often I hear people say “There’s nothing to do around here” but that’s simply not true. There are so many outdoor activities like hiking and winter sports, but there are also art studios where you can paint pottery, yoga classes, tons of great coffee shops, you just have to get out and explore!

Are you involved on campus? My campus involvement has been the Oregon Tech track and field team! It has been an incredible opportunity to represent our school as a student athlete. Every time I step on the track wearing my uniform, I am proud to be an Owl!

Have you participated in any internships or externships during your time at Oregon Tech? Did you gain valuable experience from them? I have participated in an internship at a local non-profit in Klamath Falls working with at-risk youth and teens. It has been an incredible eye-opening experience; I was able to apply so much of my knowledge from my classes to this opportunity. I developed a state-certified training program for the company to use for peer support services. This way they can partner with local clinics to get their clients the correct care they need.

Do you have employment/graduate school plans for after graduation? I am planning on moving to Bend to work with St. Charles Hospital. I want to get a few years of experience before I apply for a master's program. This way, I will be able to refer to situations I’ve experienced in the field to gain a better understanding of the material being taught!

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus, what you wish you knew before attending Oregon Tech or anything else? I wish I knew how many resources there are on campus! There are tutors for any subject you might need help with, a women's resource center, interlibrary loans, student health center, and so much more! Anything you might be struggling with, there’s a place for help at Oregon Tech. Everyone at this school wants YOU to succeed!

StudentProfile.TeaserText: I want to create a community within my hospital that provides efficient care to patients and respect across departments while also establishing a relationship with the people outside of the hospital.
StudentProfile.Biography:
Awards/Accomplishments while at Oregon Tech: Student Athletic Advisory Committee member, Dean's List Honors, All-Conference Women's Golf Honors

Why did you choose Oregon Tech? I first heard of Oregon Tech when I was being recruited for the women's golf program. I began researching the academic side and found they had the exact major I was looking for, Healthcare Management. It was a perfect fit for both my athletic and academic ambitions.

What do you like most about your program? My program requires me to have a wide variety of knowledge and so I am required to take classes like Medical Terminology and then Database Systems, for example. The diverse selection of classes keeps me very interested in my learning.

What are you passionate about changing within this particular field and why? Changing the healthcare system is near impossible for anyone, but my goal is to help lower socioeconomic communities have access to resources necessary for good health. This could include starting a clinic in an impoverished neighborhood, teaching kids in lower income schools, or reaching out to the community.

What would be your dream job? My dream job would be a CEO of a hospital. I want to create a community within my hospital that provides efficient care to patients and respect across departments while also establishing a relationship with the people outside of the hospital.

What have been some of your favorite classes and why? My favorite class has been Medical Sociology because it has taught me why different groups of people get sick and what affects them more or less. This interests me because I enjoy looking at the trends and how they change over time. 

Is there anything about Oregon Tech that you wish everyone knew about? I wish everyone knew about the Women's Golf program and our recent success these last couple years!

Are you involved on campus? I am involved in the Student Athletic Advisory Committee (SAAC), which raises athlete concerns to the university so we can build a strong relationship between the sports teams and the students at Oregon Tech. 

Is there anything more that you would like to share with future students about campus? Oregon Tech has something to offer every student on campus from robotic clubs, to Hawaiian club, to sports events! It really is great!
